text:
This is almost identical to a recipe that I love.  The only difference is that in my recipe you add 1/3 of a cup of chicken broth with the lemon juice to the pan drippings.  This helps to add the needed liquid for the sauce.  This is a fast, delicious recipe that the whole family likes.

text:
My wife loved this take on a delicious dish. Mince onion, garlic and jalepeno, add the dry ingredients called for in this dish to form a wet paste. Rub generous amounts under the skin. Outer skin is salted, rubbed with some mixture.  Broil in oven until skin gets nice and crispy (5-7 min) switch oven to bake 350 until done (approx 40 min). About half way through squeeze lime juice on chicken.

text:
I will make this easy recipe again but with some changes. I loved the spice mixture but it wasn't enough to adequately cover/rub four breasts so I had make another batch. Also, way, way, WAY too much garlic powder at the end. It overpowered the other flavors, especially the lime.  I will reduce the amount of garlic powder and double the other ingredients in the future.

text:
This recipe is five stars as written, but to spice it up, I doubled the spice mixture, increased the cayenne pepper to 1/2 tsp.  Right before finishing the "sauce" I added 1/2 cup of chicken broth per another reviewers suggetion, a "turn" of margarita mix, a splash of tequila, 1.5 tbs of honey and let bubble for two plus minutes.  Perfect mix of sweet and spice!!!

text:
This was good but needed some help.  First of all, do cut chicken breasts into pieces & pound thin.  Second, don't double the lime juice unless you want it sour.  Use 3 TBLSP first (juice of one small lime) and then taste-test the sauce, then adjust as needed.  The sauce also could benefit from a little chicken broth added when you put in the lime juice.

text:
This recipe just replaced my old Lime Chicken recipe.  It was wonderful!  So simple and easy, too.  I fixed the marinade in the morning, bumped up the heat-factor a little, used fresh cilantro from my garden (made all the difference) and threw it in a bag along with the juice of a couple limes.  I marinated it all afternoon and then threw it on the grill.  While grilling, I coated it with coarse ground pepper and squeezed fresh lime juice on each side.  Definitly a keeper!  My husband was disappointed he was travelling the next day and couldn't take the leftovers for lunch.  Instead, I sliced up the cold chicken and served it on a salad.  MMMMMMmmmmmm-good!  Thanks for the recipe!

text:
OMG! What can I add to everything that has been said before? I couldn't wait to get on here to review this recipe! Fabulous combination of flavors and just enough spice to get you going. It tasted like a restaurant meal.

I didn't change the ingredients at all -- simply doubled the spice rub because I wanted a more intense flavor.

I made only the slightest change to the directions - using a foolproof technique I learned with pork chops. I put the spice rub on the chicken about three hours before cooking. Then 30 minutes before cooking I took the chicken out of the fridge and let it "rest."

After browning, I removed the chicken, deglazed the pan with the lime juice, returned the breasts for a few minutes, then covered the pan, turned off the heat and let everything "rest" again for about 10 minutes. 

The two "resting periods" make pork chops (and chicken breasts) come out both well cooked and very moist and delicious.

This is a keeper, and I can't wait to make it again!!!

text:
I'm scratching my head over the glowing reviews. To my palate garlic powder tastes nothing at all like garlic! To me, the flavor is plain nasty. I can't understand why anyone would use a  fake-tasting product when the real thing is both inexpensive and readily available. If you want to make this dish worlds better, mash 3-4 garlic cloves to a paste. Apply to the chicken with the spices. For the sauce, mash another clove or two of garlic (or to taste) and replace that awful powder. Infinitely superior, fresh, and tasty. Try it this way - you won't believe the difference!

text:
I made it just as stated in the recipe, and it turned out fantasmic!  I did as some of the other readers suggested, and doubled the amounts on the spices, and it was enough to cover 4 skinless chicken breasts from Trader Joes.  We also had the black bean / couscous salad on this site, and it was a fabulous combination.  Not a bit left for leftovers.  

One note....Several people have commented on the sauce, and using real garlic in place of garlic powder.  It seems that will prevent the sauce from setting up.  My sauce was golden, and very smooth with a creamy texture, using the garlic powder.

I wouldn't change a thing other than the spices being doubled up for complete coverage of the breasts...otherwise, the spices may be sort of sparse!

text:
I like to use this recipe to make quick chicken soft tacos. I will usually double all the ingredients EXCEPT the salt and I omit the butter. If you mix all the ingredients together in the morning and marinate the chicken in the spices/liquid all day, you get a more flavorful end result.

country:

text:
Five stars for the ingredients & flavor, even though I prepared it my own way: Made the spice rub in the morning using 1 tsp. garlic powder, 1/2 tsp. salt & 1/8 tsp. cayenne (other spices as written). Rubbed this all over & under the skin of 4 chicken thighs & refrigerated all day. Later I combined the butter, oil, 1 clove minced garlic, lime juice & 1/3 cup chicken broth in a saucepan & let it simmer for a while to create a basting sauce. We grilled the chicken & when it was almost done we began to baste it with most of the "garlic-lime sauce" & saved a bit to pour over the top when serving. Everyone loved it, chicken stayed juicy & was full of flavor from the spice rub, then the lime sauce added a nice lift. Served with "Green Rice II" from this site for a pleasing meal! ;p

text:
I followed the recipe exactly and this chicken came out quite well. As other reviewers mentioned, you may have to double the spices to cover 4 pieces of chicken well. It depends on how spicy you'd like it. If you want more of a kick, I would double them for sure. The best thing about this recipe is that it's so quick and easy. I was worried about overcooking, so I lowered the temp a bit and covered the pan to keep it nice and juicy. When it was done, the chicken had a slight crust to it which was nice, but it stayed juicy in the center. If you don't watch this carefully, I could see how this could become a bit dry. I also used freshly squeezed lime juice (took 1.5 limes). Boyfriend approved, will make this again for sure.

text:
This is a great tasting dish that works well with my preferences for healthy food and my husband's particular tastes.  Very few dishes have the distinction of making his list of favorite meals and this is one of them.  I just made this chicken again tonight, and my husband spent the whole dinner raving about the flavor and saying "wow!" every few minutes.  This is truly a keeper and well-deserved five stars from me and the husband.  The only changes I made were cooking with virgin coconut oil (healthier than butter and olive oil, and goes well with the lime), using fresh garlic, and adding 1/4 chicken stock to increase the amount of sauce.  I served it with roasted garlic mashed potatoes and steamed broccoli.  It also reheats well, which makes it an ideal lunch to bring to work.

text:
Made recipe as is and do not taste the "spicy" in this one.  It tasted more like too much lime and salt.  So, I would suggest cutting back on the lime and salt and add more cayenne for spice to suit your level of spiciness.  Besides, when it is done and if you think it needs more salt, you can always add more to taste. This recipe for chicken also had a slightly bitter taste to it, and perhaps it would be better to use some fresh garlic, chopped or minced (whichever you prefer), and chopped onion-sauteing the garlic and onion first before adding the chicken to the pan.

userID:

Display Name:
Macha
isPro:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This turned out very good despite all the alterations I made for the Indian palate: 

1. I doubled (or tripled?!) the spices. I used regular roasted red chili flakes instead of  paprika. I also let the spice marinade sit for about 6 hours in the fridge.
2. Next time I would definitely use smaller pieces of chicken or would flatten the breasts before cooking. 
3. I used almost 6 tablespoons of some awful Lemon concentrate (Lemoneeze) instead of the lime-- half in the marinade and half while cooking. 
4. As per some other reviewers, I used about 1/8 cup of tequila for some extra kick. With the lemon it really made the chicken nice and tangy. Mmm..
5. I added water to cook the chicken at the end but next time I would use broth or stock to bulk up on the gravy which was quite yummy but not really enough to 'spoon over' the chicken. The key is to get the chicken to cook faster without absorbing all the  sauce. 
6. I put in about 8 split cloves of garlic into the butter/olive oil mix at the beginning and skipped the powder. 

I would definitely make this again!
Review:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This had great flavor. I used the full amount of seasoning for two breasts, and I would think that any less wouldn't have been enough. For health reasons, I did not use the full amount of butter, and eye-balled the olive oil, but I added a little broth when I added the lime. I also made a gravy out of the sauce by whisking in a tablespoon each of flour and water after removing the chicken. My two big criticisms are 1) that the required amount of garlic powder at the end would have been way too much, and 2) maybe it's just my stove, but the cooking time was too long. I only cooked it for about 12 minutes total, and our chicken was dry. So I'll use the recipe again, but will use my judgment with the spice levels and cooking time.
Review:
Rating:

text:
This turned out Great! I used chicken tenderloins (10 or so), they are the perfect size, thickness and are perfect for this dish. Doubled the spice mixture due to quantity of chicken. I used more olive oil because i believe a dish like this should NOT be cooked in a non stick skillet, I wanted good browning without fear of burning. Followed as written otherwise until the end, I thought 3 cloves of real minced garlic sounded better than sprinkling garlic powder, browned a few minutes then added the lime juice! Perfect, but we love garlic and it's soooo good for you. YUM! This reminded me of Red Lobsters cajun chicken linguini dish, same flavor. We'll be making this again for sure.

text:
TERRIFIC, unique, flavor and not too hot (for us). Next time, I would change 4 things, however.  I will use thinner (either pounded or cutlets)breasts, or tenders, or cut the breast into strips. Even though I marinated a few hours, the flavor didn't pentrate the thick chicken breasts. Also, would prefer SEARING on MED-HIGH heat (instead of the slower browning on medium as recipe instructs)and then finishing at med heat. Will also use the suggestions of FRESH minced garlic and adding a little chicken broth.
Think it would be 5 star, with changes.

SUPER RECIPE!!

I used 1 tablespoon black pepper, 1 teaspoon cayenne pepper, 1 teaspoon paprika and TRIPLE the Lime juice (I freshly juiced the limes myself).  This recipe has won BEST recipe ever from Allrecipes by my partner and my roommate.  I also cut the chicken breasts into large chunks (one to two bite size) and I added about 10 whole garlic cloves to the frying pan that I removed when the chicken was done and my partner and roommate put the cooked garlic on their plates and ate it with their chicken...  I served this with white rice and a salad.  Great taste!

text:
Simple recipe and preparation. Cooking in the skillet requires some real dedication in order to maintain the moisture of the poultry. Especially of note when making this recipe: make sure that the stove is set to a medium temperature when coating the chicken in the lime-garlic mixture. If not, the mixture may boil quickly and not properly flavor the chicken. Good find!

text:
This is one of my favorite dishes! I ALWAYS cut the chicken breasts into small, bite size pieces and toss them into the spice mixture. This just gives each little bite A LOT of flavor. I am not a fan of lime juice, so I use lemon juice instead. If you add some chicken broth and cornstarch to the pan after the chicken is cooked, you will get a nice creamy sauce. This is FANTASTIC served over brown or wild rice. I make this often, and always receive a lot of compliments. Thank you for this recipe!

text:
Meh. I chose this recipe because I had a lime and some cilantro I needed to get rid of. First, there wasn't anywhere near enough of the rub. The cooking time was also quite off, so by the time the breasts were cooked, the seasoning had charred, which wasn't necessarily bad, but there wasn't enough flavor to carry it.  Better bet to marinade it for a while first, use some fresh ingredients instead of everything powdered, and double the seasonings (maybe not the peppers, depending on your tastes).  Concept is good, but needs a major upgrade.

The cooking method I used was almost entirely different but I don't think that mattered, the flavors were still the same. I combined all of the spices, 4 tbsp lime juice instead of just 3, and two finely chopped garlic cloves instead of garlic powder in a bowl and let the chicken breasts marinade for a good 2-3 hours. Then I grilled them outside on a gas grill. It was so delicious, totally hit the spot for me. So aromatic and savory from the spices and a little tangy from the limes!

text:
Simple little chicken recipe that uses a potent and flavorful spice blend for a zesty taste. It was quick to prepare but I slightly adjusted the garlic content. I increased the initial garlic powder amount from ¼ tsp to ½ tsp. However, the 2 teaspoons of garlic powder called for at the end was omitted as some reviewers mentioned that it was a bit over powering. The chicken was also pounded for quicker cooking. This was going to be served with rice so a ½ cup of chicken broth was added at the end to create a sauce. Cilantro paired well with these flavors.

text:
I would love to give this recipe 5 stars, but my entire apartment filled up with smoke while making this, so I just can't. I realize I should've known better than to prepare chicken breast in a skillet, but you live, you learn. Anyway, definitely take the advice of other reviewers and BAKE the chicken in the oven. The flavor of the spices was delicious, but I also needed to double the recipe in order to have enough to cover the chicken. Also, I would probably decrease the salt next time. If you don't care about filling your whole house with smoke, my chicken came out pretty dry after following the recipe's recommended cook time for chicken breasts cut in half, so I would suggest decreasing that as well. Bottom line: great combination of spices, but best cooked in the oven!

text:
I altered this a bit.  First, I chopped some fresh cilantro and one clove of garlic, added the dry spices and seasonings (minus the garlic powder) and a couple of tablespoons of olive oil.  Cooked the chicken as directed, then removed the chicken and deglazed my pan with lime juice and 1/2 c of chicken broth (skipped the garlic powder).  I allowed that to reduce and then returned the chicken to the pan to warm it again.  It was light and delicious!  Went very well with Cilantro Lime Rice from this site.

text:
After reading reviews, I wasn't sure if this recipe needed more spices or just more coating so I added a tablespoon of flour to the spices.  It needs more spices, not flour.  It was very subtle.  Very.  Not bad at all, but not wowing either.  I didn't do the additional garlic on top, but added more to the spice blend.  All amounts the same except for reducing the thyme to 1/8t & increasing garlic to 1/2t.  I used half cup chicken broth & 2T lime juice for the sauce - thickened it with a T flour.  Only E liked the sauce & not a lot at that.  It wasn't bad either, just not any big deal.  I doubt I'll make it again.  'Worth trying, but be sure to increase the spices.  Oh, & if you want spicy hot, you'll have to really increase the hot spices.  This is more liked spiced, not spicy.

I doubled everything for the rub, since some people said it wasn't enough. It was very, very flavorful. I meant to add chicken broth to the final sauce, but forgot. It would have thinned it out a bit, so I wish I had.   Hubby's only complaints were (a) chicken was a bit dry, and (b) he wished I had used boneless thighs, as he's not really white meat person. I think that the cooking times were too much for the chicken that I used - 3 breasts, each cut in half and tenderized slightly. Should have seen that coming, not the recipe's fault.  In general, very good and flavorful. Good to serve with rice and a veggie. Will make again.

text:
Oh my this was a hit! My roommates love Mexican but we always made it with ground beef. I wanted to try something on the more healthy side so I found this recipe and put a twist on it. Followed the directions until the last 10min of cooking. Took all the chicken off and cut it into cubes, some was still raw and this is ok. Put it back into the pan, added some water for moisture and sautéed for another 10 minutes. Came out wonderful and perfect for tacos, or taco salad as I had it with. Mixed with the Mexican quinoa recipe instead of rice and it was a hit!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a great recipe. However, I changed it slightly by doubling the cayenne pepper in the dry rub. In the sauce I added chopped onions and used minced garlic (1-2 tbs depends on your preference of garlic; I love garlic so I used 2 tbs)instead of garlic powder. Also, I cut my half chicken breast in half so it was about 1/2 inch thick, and would not burn the outside of the chicken when cooking. I also did not have any lime, but had a bunch of fresh lemons a friend gave me and substituted the lemon for the lime and still came out fantastic! The dry rub has an excellent flavor and my husband enjoyed it very much as well. I served it with rice and steamed vegetables (broccoli, bell peppers and carrots).

text:
this was good chicken!  i had to nix the cayenne for the kiddos, and my 5 year old was still having fits at the table because it was too spicy (the black pepper i guess?) i also set off the smoke alarm with this, i guess cooking with butter at too high of a heat is what did it.  next time, i'd use just olive oil.  i also didn't have enough leftover to make a  sauce, so as others have said, next time i'd also add chicken broth to get enough to make sauce.  it would be good to dip bread in.  all in all, very flavorful chicken that we all enjoyed!  thanks!

text:
This recipe was OK.  My 10-year-old son told me it was good but not my best chicken.  My husband just kinda shook his head and agreed that it was good.  Those were mediocre responses from my boys.  I followed the recipe pretty exactly -- I didn't have parsley flakes, so I left them out. I don't know if the lime juice curdled the butter or what, but I did not spoon the oily mess over the chicken breasts.  I tried to save it by turning it into a sort-of gravy/sauce mixture, but that didn't work.  As far as the chicken itself went, like I said, it was good but "not my best," and I like to use premium dried spices... Maybe, if there's a next time, I'll try fresh garlic as fresh is almost always better.

country:
None
text:
Made it to the letter the 1st time and it was excellent. 
The 2nd time I made fajitas out of it by making the following changes: sliced the breasts into strips, replaced the butter with olive oil, doubled the lime juice/garlic powder at the end for more liquid, added a pepper of each color (red, orange, yellow, green, all cut into strips) and 1/2 an onion, cooked the veggies until crisp/tender. Served it all in heated corn tortillas
This is delicious on its own and even better with the modifications.

text:
My family loves this recipe.  The only thing I've changed is that I don't fry the chicken on the stovetop, but instead grill it.  I follow the recipe above, except I grill the chicken for 7 minutes a side, and baste the boneless breast of chicken with the lime juice / garlic combo during cooking.    This eliminates the need for the butter.

None
text:
I would say this is good with exception to WAY TO MUCH SALT.  Holy cow!  It would be perfect with about a 1/4 teaspoon salt instead.  It over powers all the other wonderful flavors.  Salt is supposed to bring the flavor out, not take over.  Also, the serving size does not yield enough for 4 normal sized breasts, maybe that is why the salt is overpowering...I would double the amounts of everything but the salt.  1/2 teaspoon salt would be good for the doubling of everything else for 4 breasts.  Then I would say PERFECT!  Nice and easy though with a different spin on lime chicken...which I love. ;)

text:
This recipe was good, but I don't think it was 5 star good.  I had two large chicken breasts, so I butterflied them.  I don't think that thick breasts would work well with this recipe.  I did not take the other reviewers' advice to double the sauce, so I really didn't have any.  It was also a bit too sour for us, so if you're not a huge fan of lime, cut out a TB or so. It was very quick to make, and I made it into a light dinner with brown rice and brussel sprouts. I'll make it again, but it is just not one of our favorites!

Very Good!!!  I didn't want to use the stove, so I used the grill!  I was glad I did :) After combining the first 7 ingredients, I rub the mix all over the chicken breasts and let it sit in the fridge for about 3 hours.  I combined butter, olive oil and lime juice and used it as a baste.  I baste frequently & generously (every time I turned the chicken over).  It smelled great while cooking.  The chicken turned out moist and just very flavorful.  My guests loved them!  Thanks for sharing.  I have found yet another favorite that my family loves.

region:

country:

text:
Wow, this was flavorful and delicious and SOOOOOO quick and easy to make.  I made the whole dinner in a few minutes flat.  It took a little longer to cook, but prep time was next to nothing.  This was probally the quickest 5 star meal yet!  I did make a few changes.  I only used 2 chicken breast, and cut them into strips.  I used all the seasonings for the rub and did not cut them in half.  I used cajun seasoning instead of cayenne powder, because that was what I had on hand.  I cut the chicken in strips before seasoning.  I cut the garlic to sprinkle on the chicken after it had cooked to 1 tsp. and cut the lime juice to 2 Tbsp.  I made rice a roni fried rice flavor with peas added to the rice as a side dish and voila!!  Dinner in less than 1/2 an hour!!

text:
Wow, this was superb!  The only changes I made were doubling the herb mix, cutting my large chicken breasts in half length wise and omitting the butter. A key ingredient; the garlic powder makes this.  Don't get me wrong.  I love using fresh garlic, but somehow the powder makes the sauce more substantial.  There is a place for garlic powder in cooking and this is a perfect use of it!  Try the recipe close to "as is".  I see no need to add chicken broth at all, because that's a whole different recipe!  I'll be making this  often...delicious!

Display Name:
Marla Robichaud

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2028985.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great lime chicken! I made this tonight but did not add the lime until the 15 minutes total cooking time were done - cooking lime makes it sour.  I also prepared a cup of chicken broth and kept spooning it over the chicken while it was cooking and it helped with creating a sauce to pour over the chicken. I added one garlic clove to the last 2 minutes of cooking time. Last, I scraped what was left and added 3 tablespoons of lime and spooned it on the chicken. My kids (10 & 13) devoured it.  I would cut the salt to 1/4 teaspoon next time as I thought it was too salty. I also put the chicken with the rub on it in a gallon size bag in the fridge for a couple hours until I was ready to cook it at dinner time, saved on prep time, cleaning time and could do that in the morning before work, etc.  Served this with a side of coleslaw and it was a delicious and healthy dinner.

userID:
4100021
Display Name:
justina8463

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674134.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I followed some other reviews on this and I literally make this once a week. I use boneless chicken with skin on. I use the spices listed but double the recipe so I have plenty. I add some fresh garlic instead of powdered garlic and mix in some lime juice to form a paste. I then mince half a jalapeño and add it to my paste.  I take generous spoonfuls of the paste and rub it under the skin, using a little on the outside of the skin as well. I salt and pepper the skin and put it in the broiler for 7 minutes so it gets nice and crispy, then reduce to bake at 350 for about 18 minutes. This chicken comes out full of flavor, very juicy and even better for lunch the next day. I love this recipe with a side of brown rice and some vegetables - it's easy, healthy and delicious. Thanks!!

userID:
13741572
Display Name:
Dominick Senese
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
19
favoritesCount:
59
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674161.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This tastes AWESOME, but the original recipe HAS to be adjusted.  There is WAY too little spice mixture to "sprinkle generously" on both sides.  I never use salt to cook with, leaving others to salt to taste, so I tripled the quantities of the spice mixture without any salt to have enough for one batch, or double it with the salt.  Regarding thick or thin chicken, if you are easily overpowered by lime, then use thinner pieces.  To me, the lime is the flavor that really zings in this and the thicker pieces can absorb more of the lime flavor so you taste more in each bite.  As for the garlic powder to use in the pan at the end, I just coated each piece with a fine layer of garlic powder directly from the shaker, coating the pieces as I would shake garlic powder onto a slice of pizza. If you LOVE garlic, as I do, then coat both sides.  Also, the cooking time, obviously, is greatly adjusted with the thinner pieces if you choose to use them.

Finally, I enjoyed this so much, I made a shaker of this spice mixture for use at any time.  To do this, I first put the parsley in the small mixing bowl and crushed it fine so it would come out of a shaker.  I tried using a shaker with bigger holes but the mix came out too fast and still slightly clogged with larger parsley flakes.  If you have a mortar and pestle that is obviously the best to use to crush the parsley, but if not you can use the sides or bottom of a spoon in a rounded bowl and it does it pretty quickly.
Review:
Rating:
5

2014-06-21T14:08:09.567

text:
This recipe is now a staple in my kitchen, and I'm not not even a huge fan of meat. However I have made a few changes to the spice mixtures (as suggested by other reviewers). First of all, I am not hesitant to double or triple all of the spices except for the cayenne pepper. The extra spices in the juice that we serve over the chicken and corn are just a bonus. Also we sauteed garlic and onion with the chicken and omit the garlic powder at the end (since we are already using garlic). This pairs very well with corn.

text:
I'm giving it 4 stars based on following the recommendations of the reviewers, but to give it 5 stars, I would still continue to modify the recipe.  For 4 pieces of chicken, I doubled the spices except I left the salt as is because people complained that it was too salty.  I LOVED the flavor and light heat; however; it was STILL too salty.  For 5 stars, the salt content would still have to be reduced.  I liked it more than my husband, who said it was "just ok".  In fact, he ended up pouring salsa, a bit of sour cream, and cheese on top and said that it was pretty good.  It's an easy dish, and I would make again, but I would definitely reduce the salt even more.

This was very good!  I did make a few changes though: doubled the spices but made the mistake of not increasing the lime juice.  After I browned the chicken, I removed it from the pan, sauteed some onions and garlic, then added a little chicken stock and cooked it down for a few minutes before adding the chicken back in to finish cooking.  I spooned the sauce over the chicken when serving. Nice and spicy but not too much-I don't care for much heat.   I will make this one again for sure!

text:
We really liked this! Easy to fix. I pretty much followed the recipe except used up 3 chicken breasts I had (sliced them in to small pieces before cooking in olive oil (no butter used). Also sliced up a portabello mushroom to add in to mix. Seemed like I needed more liquid so I added about a cup of low-sodium V8 juice. Next time I'd probably add some chicken stock too. Covered this and simmered for about 45 minutes. When done, I added 1-2 Tbsp of sour cream. Served over brown rice. Spicy, tasty, and easy!!!

recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3465388.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
It’s a KEEPER!!  Not just an occasional dinner it will go on the rotation. I too made some adjustments. I didn’t have cayenne pepper so I used red pepper and added a little extra. I also added a little extra of smoked paprika. I used 1 small clove of fresh garlic and a sprinkle of garlic powder in the rub instead of just powder. I had plenty of time so I marinated the chicken with the rub for about 4-5 hours. After cooking the chicken, I combined the lime juice, garlic powder and ½ cup of chicken broth and cooked for 5 minutes, removed the chicken and added some flour to thicken the sauce, replaced chicken for a few minutes and served it with white rice and green beans and Italian bread.

This recipe was great, it's my husband's new, hands down, all time favorite chicken recipe! Personally it was too spicy for me, but I can't handle a lot of spice to begin with.

My husband likes it so much he wants me to make it again for all of his friends. All in all a very tasty, very easy and quick recipe!

ilikeitspicy

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have been making this regularly forever now and just realized I haven't reviewed the recipe!  It is a standby favourite!  I omit the parsley and double the cayenne.  As others have suggested, I double the spice mixture, more is better!    Instead of garlic powder, I use fresh near the end (1-2 cloves) and add a couple splashes of tequila (at the same time as the lime juice).  I also skip the butter all together.  As I usually only make one serving at a time, I end up using a whole lime for the juice.  I serve it with garlic mashed potatoes. That seems to help offset some of the heat.  I love, love, love this recipe!  And whenever I make it for others, they rave as well! Satisfying all around!   This recipe has been fondly renamed "Tequila Chicken"!  Thank you C. Perez!

text:
I'm usually pretty lazy about rating but made this recipe with minor modifications for friends last night and was blown away.  So easy and SO fabulous.

My changes included doubled the spice mixture - we all liked spicy food, so I decided to risk it.  I also used minced garlic (not powdered) in the sauce and added a fresh, diced jalapeno while the chicken was cooking.  I seeded it this time, but may include some seeds for extra kick next time.  Like another reviewer, I pounded my chicken breasts to make them thinner.  I also added a shot of tequila to the sauce after the chicken was cooked and let it simmer.  The end result was delicious.  So very impressed!

text:
Fantastic dish!!!  I doubled the Cayenne, but we like it hot here.  I agree with other posters, the garlic at the end is WAY too much.   I only add 1/2 teaspoon but I also add another dash or two of cayenne and 3 tablespoons of lemon juice and 2 tablespoons of water or white vinegar to help fill out the sauce.  I love having extra sauce to pour over my jasmine white rice as well, so it is quite easy to double the sauce.  A BIG "Thank you!" to the poster for sharing this wonderful dish.  This is one of our favorites!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was good but I’ll admit … I made some alternations based on previous reviews.  I followed the recipe to a tee except I sauteed the chicken breasts in two fillets to make two and make them a little thinner (didn’t feel like pounding), browned them on each side until they had a slight crust, removed them from the pan, poured in chicken broth and added a little water and some chicken bouillon cubes, and let the chicken simmer in that with a lid on the pan.  I served whole kernel corn with fresh cilantro, salt and butter, and a fresh garden salad on the side.  Without that chicken broth I don’t think there would be enough “juices”.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I followed the comments of another reviewer and added 1/3 cup of chicken broth to the sauce. It balanced out the lime nicely, so there are definite notes of lime and garlic but they aren't overpowering. I only added 2 Tbsp of lime juice, and omitted the onion powder since I was out. My parents went crazy for it! I added some rice to the final product, and will be cutting up the smallest pieces of chicken to add to my salads :) Side note: definitely use chicken breasts for this recipe. I used thighs, because that's what I had, and I had to cook them an additional half hour in the oven. A thinner cut of chicken should cook all the way on the skillet.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love this chicken.  The thing I love the most is that it is so EASY!  It has just the right amount of spiciness, enough that you notice, but not too much that it makes you sweat.  A couple of changes: I used only 1 tsp. garlic powder because I didn't want it to overpower everything else, I also used sea salt instead of table salt (since it's coarser, the same measurement will give you less salt overall).  I served it with "Awesome and Easy Creamy Corn Casserole" from this site, and the two went perfectly together.  I will make this again!

text:
This recipe was a bit too spicy and strong on thyme for my taste. For a more mild dish that still has a little kick, try these measurements: 1 tsp black pepper 1/4 cayenne 1/2 tsp paprika  1 tsp garlic powder 1/2 tsp onion powder 1/2 tsp thyme 1 tsp parsley I used on thin sliced chicken breasts for a stronger spice flavor, and served with extra lime. Yum!

text:
I made this last night for my husband who is the worlds greatest guiny pig. I tested it on him because I want to make it for my church this coming Sunday. He didn"t say too much. I, on the other hand, thought it was wonderful. But, you know what? He didn't have to say anything. He kept going back into the skillet eating what was left. Actions speak louder than words. Thank you C, Perez. Will be making this for church and home again  and again! I forgot to mention that I did take the advise of other reviewers and added  chicken broth and I pounded it out a little.
4/21/10 Had church fellowship. The menu was fried, grilled and bbq chicken, potato salad, and green beans. Of course, I added the Spicey Garlic Lime Chicken on my own. THEY WENT CRAZY.  It was like word of mouth. I asked them to try it. After they tried it they started spreading the news. There was none left. You can really tweak this recipe. Because I quadrupled the recipe (I used 16 chicken breasts) I had a lot more sauce, but still needed a little more. I pounded the chicken as suggested by one reviewer and added 1 cup of chicken broth as suggested by another reviewer. Because there was more liquid than I had in the original I thickened it a little with a mixture of cornstarch and water.
Because i flattened the breast, which made them appear larger, I was able to cut them in half after they were cooked. So, I had 32 pieces of chicken.
Next time I will add more chicken broth and maybe some mushrooms and onions.

text:
Definitely yummy and I didn't have to go out and buy anything - all of these ingredients were on my spice rack so it didn't require a trip to the grocery store.  Definitely makes a spicy chicken dish but not hard to make at all.  I will say that I only used two chicken breast halves for the amount of spice recommended and it was the right amount so I think that you would have to increase it for the quantity of chicken recommended in the recipe.  Also, I substituted fresh minced garlic for garlic powder.  Instead of using garlic powder at the end I just added another tablespoon of lime juice.  Tasty and spicy!

country:
None
text:
This is a great easy chicken recipe that is a hit every time! I use this recipe for 2 chicken breasts instead of 4. I always use fresh minced garlic instead of powder, double the cayenne (we like heat!), and add chopped fresh cilantro then let it all marinade in a ziploc bag for 3-4 hours before cooking. To change it up occassionally, I'll remove the breasts after they're done cooking and add sliced onions to the pan, saute until tender, then add a cornstarch slurry to make a delicious gravy to top the chicken served over cilantro rice. Yum! Thank you for this great chicken recipe!

text:
Delicious.  I make this chicken at least once a week.  The only modification I made was slicing in the chicken on both sides and I sprinkled the spice mixture inside so the seasonings would cook inside the chicken as well.  The chicken breasts I used were pretty thick, so slicing them gave the chicken a more consistent flavor throughout.  

To save time, I made four portions of the seasonings ahead of time and have the mix in it's own spice jar.  That cut the prep time even more on this quick dish.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I followed another poster's advice and I made a paste w/ onion, jalapeno, garlic, a few tbsp chicken bouillon and the seasonings it called for. I added it all to the blender and pureed. I rubbed it in and under the drumsticks, sprinkled w/ a little more salt and broiled 5 min to brown.  Then I let bake for 20 min.  I brushed on the sauce (in which I had put 1 T. honey, lime juice, garlic and butter) and let bake for 20 more min.  it was very good, but even w/ the jalapeno, it wasn't very spicy.  Even the 3 year old liked it.  Making the paste ensured that no picky children saw any onions or peppers to turn their nose up to.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Just wanted to let people know that you can do this with a whole chicken. (I didn't have any chicken breasts).  Double the spice mixture (use the recipe converter at the bottom to make it easier)... and rub it all over the chicken as well as inside of the chicken.  Place 2-3 cut-up limes inside the chicken as well.  Put the olive oil and/or butter on top of the chicken.  Put the whole thing in the oven at 400 degrees for about an hour.  Delish.

country:
None
text:
Hubby said it was the best chicken dish I'd ever made (see photo).

I made some changes however: I used a Japanese free-range chicken thigh instead of chicken breast because they have more flavor and are easier to cook.  I also only used half the chicken but smothered on the entire amount of spice mixture to give it an extra kick, and I let the chicken sit with the spice on for a few minutes before cooking.  When frying, I cut down the butter in half to make it less greasy.  

We had it with white rice and Zucchini Mediterranean Style for a lovely dinner.

None
text:
We eat lots of chicken and were getting tired of traditional ways of preparing chicken as well as casseroles. I was looking for a good chicken recipe that could be cooked on top of the stove, not fried, baked, roasted, or included in a casserole. (Time is a factor.)
This was a great recipe. It was delicious and easy to prepare. I used boneless, skinless chicken thighs as I am not fond of chicken breast. Otherwise, I followed the recipe as written with few changes. I did double the recipe for the seasoning. The chicken was delicious! Even my elderly mother enjoyed it and she is very particular about her chicken. It tasted like I spent a lot of time preparing it, but I didn't. I served it with sides of lemon-garlic rice with rosemary and broccoli. Yum! I will definitely make this again,and will probably serve on Sunday when the family comes for dinner.

We loved this.  Followed other reviews and doubled the spice mix, using fresh garlic paste and a bit of olive oil to make a paste. Plenty spicy, but not too much for our taste.

text:
The first time I made it, medium heat on stove-top was too high, which blackened the chicken. Also, i spritzed too much lime on chicken, which overpowered it. Second time i made it, i cooked it on stove-top with heat between low and medium; it slowly sizzled/simmered. I spritzed less lime and added shredded cheese on top of chicken during the last 1-2 minutes of cooking. Made all the difference in the world.

text:
I made this recipe last night with slight changes. I used boneless, skinless thighs instead of breast. I didn't have paprika so I omitted that. I also put in 1 tsp salt, 1/2 tsp dried parsley and 1/2 tsp garlic powder. Instead of using the mixture as dry rub, I added 2 tbsp of light virgin olive oil and then the lime to make a marinade. I marinated the thighs for about 2 hours, although it would be best to marinade for at least 6 hours. Then I grilled it instead of sautéing. It was delicious!

Darrah Karnes

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7065089.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm not sure if it's fair to give this recipe 5 stars because I really went rogue with it to make it healthier, but I generally followed the ingredients. First, I doubled the spices and sprinkled that over my chicken breasts. Next, I put all of the lime juice on top of the raw, seasoned chicken. Then, I ditched the butter, using more olive oil in its place. I put all of the oil on top of the seasoned chicken, covered the bowl, and let it marinate for a little over an hour. Last, I put the chicken and all of the juices from the bowl on a rimmed baking sheet and baked the chicken at 400 degrees until it was cooked (about 30 minutes.) The changes I made were really accidental (I should probably learn to READ directions) but the result was beyond delicious and absolutely a keeper!!! I can't wait to try the recipe as written!

userID:
2364681
Display Name:
KIS_2000
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
33
favoritesCount:
716
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/46327.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was fantastic!  I served as soft tacos.  Per other reviews I doubled the spice ingredients and added about 1 ½ tsp ground cumin.  I cut the chicken into bite sized pieces put in a Ziploc bag added a drizzle of olive oil, dumped in the spice mix and mushed it all together.  I put the chicken in the fridge for about 2 hrs.  Thirty minutes before cook time I took the chicken out of the fridge and let it rest on the counter.  I sautéed the chicken in 3 batches with the olive oil and butter.  After browning the chicken I kept warm in the oven.  I deglazed the pan with the lime juice and about 1/3 c. of chicken stock. I then add the chicken back to the pan and let simmer for about 15 -20 min so the sauce could reduce and coat the chicken.  I served in warm soft tortilla shells with lettuce, tomato, cheese, Crema Mexicana and several healthy splashes of Salsa Picante de Chile Habanero!! Be warned if you don’t like it spicy don’t add the Habanero. I served this with Black Bean and Couscous Salad (also from this site) which was also very good.  The entire family loved it and has requested that I make this often.

text:
Super tasty, I reduced the salt and garlic as suggested by others. Advise not over coating the chicken with the spices until you figure out how much suits you. I use the juice of one lime, the limes I use are a nice size, app. 2.5 inches long and 2 in. in diameter. Give it a whirl, doubt you'll be disappointed, my entire family enjoys this recipe.

text:
Delicious! Just make sure your chicken breasts aren't too thick. Mine got a little overdone cuz my chicken breasts were really thick in spots. Cook on medium like the recipe says. I served mine is soft tortilla bowls filled with the sliced chicken, spanish rice, black beans, corn, shredded cheese, and salsa verde. Yummy! Can't wait to make this again!!! 17 year old son loved it!

region:

country:
None
text:
I've made this recipe several times now.  Very simple and if your meat isn't frozen, can be ready in about 10 minutes.  It's one of my go-to meals when I want a good meal after work but don't want to spend a lot of time.  My husband loves it as is, but sometimes I reduce the red pepper, black pepper, and paprika because I don't like as much heat.  I've used chicken tenders instead of breasts and the only difference is cook time.  There always ends up several tablespoons of "sauce" in the pan after the chicken is cooked, so we like to pair the dish with mashed potatoes and use the sauce as gravy.

text:
My very picky husband likes this – second time making it – I cut chicken breasts into strips, covered with spice combination, with a little olive oil in frying pan began cooking, no – poured lime juice (in the bottle easy lime juice) I passed on the butter. The sauce was so GOOD – but not sticking, so I took a cube of chicken bullion with a teaspoon of corn starch and ½ cup water - oh so good – I spooned modest amount of sauce as saturating as possible on my strips – this is on my ‘husband will eat this’ list! Next time will make more sauce and serve this on rice or noodles.

text:
This was outstanding! I always read the reviews before I try a recipe. I did double the spices and I cut the large chicken breasts in half and the pounded them slightly. I used crushed garlic instead of the garlic powder and added minced onion and jalapeño pepper in the last five minutes. All suggestions in the reviews. It is a yum. Tender, moist and snappy.

Display Name:
BillyandChristy

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674130.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a great "base" recipe for me to use.  I had some of the ingredients on hand and subbed in the rest (new kitchen not fully stocked).  Fresh lemon for lime, chili powder for cayenne, and no oregano.  I also used a little less salt since lemon can be a salt replacement.  Since we like a lot of flavor, I tripled the seasoning and doubled the butter. We loved the flavor combination of garlic/citrus/heat.  I also served baked sweet potatoes plain that we seasoned with some of the pan drippings.  My husband said even though he doesn't normally like baked sweet potatoes, he really like them with this seasoning. Based on our experience and the other reviews, this is a great recipe to customize to your personal taste while giving you some general guidelines.

text:
Only change was that I decreased the cayenne just a touch preseasoned the chicken breasts that I had planed in half and pounded to be a little thinner. Sauteed in olive oil in batches then deglazed the pan with the lime juice and butter. I did triple the sauce for 7 full breasts (14 pieces when planed). To make sure they were done and the sauce flavored everything, I put the chicken back in the sauce and covered it and let it braise in the oven so it would hold for late arrivals. Very good. Husband loved it and a picky 2 year old who doesn't normally like chicken asked for 2nds.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
My Husband And I Made This Tonight.  We Love Lime So We Made Some Small Adjustments To Make This Delicious Recipe That Much Better.  We Didn't Have Chicken Breasts So We Used Chicken Tenders.  We Added A Zest Of Two Limes.  Most Of The Zest Went Into The Spice Mixture That Was Put On The Outside Of The Chicken.  We Put Some Of The Zest In The Sauce.  We Also Juiced Two Limes For The Sauce And Added 2 1/2 Tsp. Of Garlic Powder To The Sauce.  We Paired It With A Few Sides: Rice, Black Beans, And A Corny Lime Salad We Made Up On The Spot.  I Think The Next Time We Will Take Some Advice We Saw On Some Of The Reviews And Add Some Chicken Stock To Make More Of A Sauce For The Chicken And The Rice.  All In All It Was A Good Recipe And We Will Be Having It Again And Again.  Thanks So Much For Posting It.

text:
I made this for a work potluck and received rave reviews! I took six jumbo chicken breasts and pounded them so they were semi-flat, then cut them in half to make 12 servings. I then rubbed the spice mixture on both sides and refrigerated them overnight (instead of tripling the mixture, I quadrupled the mixture for an extra kick). I threw them on the grill for lunch, and basted them on both sides with the garlic and lime juice upon turning them. We then ate them as sandwiches. They turned out spectacular!!!

We were looking for a recipe for the bbq grill.  I modified this recipe to accommodate that.  After adding the rub to the chicken, I put it in flat dish, and drizzled the remaining ingredients over the chicken, covered it and let it marinate about 6 hours in the refrigerator.  Just before grilling, I added another squeeze of lime to each chicken piece.  It came out delicious!

userID:
8510301
Display Name:
bitterquill
isPro:
False

0

madeRecipesCount:
102
favoritesCount:
10
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674153.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was delicious. Two teaspoons of garlic powder seemed like a lot to me (and I *love* garlic), so I halved it. I also used a slightly smaller measurement of thyme because mine was ground. If your chicken breasts are on the larger side, you will want to slightly increase the cooking time. For those saying there wasn't enough liquid, given the oiliness of it, I think it's supposed to be more of a basting liquid than a sauce. However, you could easily deglaze the pan with some chicken stock and whisk in a little flour and milk to make a gravy. Other than possibly having too much garlic as written, I thought this was fantastic. It was so easy and I always have all the ingredients on hand, and the results are really flavorful (really nice with a whole wheat roll to wipe up the excess). I will definitely make it again.

I've made this a few times and honestly, this is amazing!   You may want to double up on the spices, really good but not enough.  It's great as is but I prefer baking it at 375 for about 40-45 mins, less messy.  I also prefer boneless thighs over breasts because they're juicier.  Since I bake them, I put tiny dots of butter under each thigh along with the evoo, added fresh diced garlic on top and some red pepper flakes.  Forgot the lime juice last time but it was still delicious.

text:
I don't think I like the taste of lime with my chicken...so take my review with a grain of salt.  I mixed the rub as directed and covered the chicken in it.  I first sauteed oil (no butter) and some garlic and onions. I then browned the meat (dark) and added some veggies (red, yellow, orange peppers, celery, tomatoes).  whenever the pan got a bit to dry, I deglazed with some white wine or chicken broth.  1.5T lime juice added at the end.  I think maybe the tomatoes and the lime was too much?  If I repeat this recipe, I'll omit the tomatoes.

text:
I followed the recipe as best I could with what I had on hand. I didn't have any cayenne, so I used a little cumin and chilli powder instead. I also brushed the chicken with a tiny bit of honey before I seasoned it. I only used half the butter, more on accident than anything, and I think I'll try to remember next time, cause the chicken was a little dry. Of course my husband loves his chicken to be dry for some reason, so that was fine for him, but for normal people, definitely keep the butter! I also used fresh squeezed limes for the juice. I don't know if it makes a huge difference, but hey, why not? Thanks for the recipe. I'll be making this again very soon!

text:
This is so delicious. I found that making the marinade by adding olive oil and a bit of ground ginger then letting it set at room temperature for an hour intensifies the flavor. I paired this up with coconut white rice. Boil in a bag white rice in half water and half coconut milk. Add dried chives to the rice.  Gave it a carribbean flavor. *this dish is not for the weak-tongued* it is spicy!!!

text:
LOVED this recipe and so did my family.  I left out the butter for health/calorie reasons and I mixed up two batches of the spices because I had large chicken breasts.  Dipped the breasts in the first batch on one side and sprinkled the second batch on top.  Did not use the additional garlic power for this reason.  Poked holes in my cooked breasts before adding the lime juice.  Served with brown rice that I mixed in the broth from the chicken.  Delicious!!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674167.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The family enjoyed this dish, served over a bed of shite rice. I word about the spice mix, it is VERY potent. I doubled the batch to accomodate a larger amount of chicken. I would say that you could stick to the original amount for 4-6 servings. It has very good flavor, but if you overdo it, you end up overpowering everything else. I also skipped the second addition of garlic powder, and I am glad I did, it probably would have blown our heads off! When they say "sprinkle miture" they mean it. If you "coat" it, you will probably end up with the same super-spicy results. We will be making this again for sure, I will make sure to watch the spice levels the next time.

We made this last night, and it was a real hit.  I ended up having to quadruple the spices to put on 4 chicken breasts, and also added 1/3 cup chicken stock at the end.  Only problem was that it was too salty.  In the future, I will add the chicken stock, and cut back on the salt.  Also, while I quadrupled the spices, I did not do that with the cayenne.  I think it would've been too spicy then.  I thought the heat was just right.  Will definitely be making this again!

userID:
7790956
Display Name:
AMCCARNEY
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
4
favoritesCount:
874
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/731925.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I totally went off on a beaten path with this one. One thing led to another and next I knew I had a casserole. Where I started wrong was pulling boneless ckn thighs instead of breasts, BUT IT TURNED OUT SOOO DELISH!!! It's a must share...

After cooking the thighs as directed in the recipe, I cut them into chunks letting them shred the was they wanted. I sauteed 1/2 each of a red, yellow, and orange pepper. Threw in a 1/2 can of black beans, corn, and jalapenos letting them saute in a little of the seasoning mentioned in the recipe as well as a squirt of lime until peppers were just tender... The I took a box of Zatarain's Black Bean and Rice and stirred it into my veggies (cooking as directed on the box w/ less water). 

While the rice was fluffing, I decided to make a cheese sauce out of Hollandaise. Now this is the secret, as the hollandaise was starting to thicken I added pico de gallo style salsa to it, cilantro and mexican style shredded chz (can't tell ya cup measurements as I just added a little bit at a time until I reached the desired texture). cooked until chz was melted and hollandaise was thickened.

Then I pulled out my casserole dish and stirred in the ckn and my rice creation, topped it with my chz mixture and popped it in the oven at 375* for about 20 mins, turned my oven on to broil LO and hit the top layer for a sec to make the chz layer just lightly browned and bubbly. Topped with some grn chives and ate with tortillas... REALLY WORTH A TRY!!!! SOOOO YUMMY
Review:

5

Good and quick! I pounded the chicken breasts to let them cook more evenly. I doubled the recipe but did not need to double the oil/butter. I finished them in the oven at 350 instead of on the stove until internal temp read 160. I did add chicken broth (about 1/3 c. for this amt.) and thickened it with a little cornstarch on the stove after baking. Very good!

Review:
Rating:

userID:
2917215
Display Name:
Mommy3_4_blue
isPro:
False

0

madeRecipesCount:
8
favoritesCount:
59
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677179.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was AWESOME!!  Even my little boys (ages 4 and 6) loved it!  I did it a little different.  I took fresh garlic and put it in the food processor (actually, I probably used 5 or 6 cloves from a package of already peeled garlic I needed to use up), added a few tablespoons of olive oil, minced that up, added half of a small onion, minced that up, added the salt, black pepper, cayenne pepper, paprika, then added some fresh parsley (about a handful unchopped) and a some fresh thyme I had leftover from another recipe.  Haven't a clue how much thyme, just 3 or 4 sprigs, and mixed it all up in a food processor.  Then I took chicken breasts, cut them in half (to make 2 thin slices), coated all the chicken with the paste and then cooked them on the skillet.  When they were browned and cooked through, I took them out, added 1/2 C or so chicken broth with the lime juice and deglazed the pan.  Then added the chicken back in the pan to coat with the glaze and finish cooking.  Plated them and poured the glaze over the top.  DELISH!!  Will be making this a regular at our house!!

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Thanks for a tasty chicken recipe! I did use fresh garlic as I really don't like the powder and can taste it a mile away. I also had fresh thyme and parsley on hand so I used it as well.  As others suggested I added tequila (1 tbsp) with the lime juice.  My chicken was very thick, so after adding the lime I had to cook it about 10 more minutes instead of the recommended 5.  Because of the extended cooking time the sauce reduced down to a very nice glaze on the chicken. I was very pleased. My husband and I both really enjoyed the flavors, and that is saying a lot - I'm not a big fan of chicken recipes typically.  Thanks again for something I will be making again and again!

text:
This dish was great!! I mixed all the seasonings together and diced up three small cloves of garlic. I sprinkled some of the seasoning on the cutting board and half of the garlic. I put the chicken on top and sprinkled the remaining seasoning on the chicken, covered it with saran wrap and pounded it out thin. This was really gets the seasoning and the garlic into the chicken. I also doubled the cayenne as someone else had suggested and served with a fresh salad. The man absolutely loved it, will make again!!!

None
text:
Simple, yet fantastic recipe!  I like seasoning so I did 1/4 tsp of everything and used it on just two chicken breasts and that amount was perfect for us.  I also used the full amount of the lime juice.  It wasn't very spicy, but it was extremely flavorful and juicy.  No dry chicken with this recipe!  And the best part?  It's seriously low calorie for those (like me) who are watching their weight.

text:
This is a great recipe if you cut out the garlic powder at the end. It's not needed and 2 teaspoons is too much anyway and it's already in the rub. I took the advice of another reviewer doubled both the rub ingredients and the sauce. I added 2/3 cup of really good quality chicken broth to the pan drippings along with the lime juice. I thickened the sauce with a little cornstarch mixed with water. I might cut back on the amount of lime juice a tad next time because it was really "citrusy" a little more than I would like but it was still so very good. The thickened sauce goes really well over rice.  Thanks for a great recipe.

text:
I would love to give this 4.5 stars.  The seasoning was very tasty, maybe a bit less zesty than I was expecting, but not overwhelming at all which I was worried about with all the garlic.  The best part of this recipe is the method of cooking, meaning coating with an herb mixture and cooking in the right amount of garlic and butter. The recommendation of 6 minutes a side turned out to be perfect and I will take to other recipes with me because cook time for chicken has always been a mystery to me.  Also, on a positive note, I was surprised by how much "juice" this recipe generated. Reading the recipe, I was expecting a more dry finish. I was pleased by the wetness and I would have made a side of rice had I realized.

text:
This was really good, and I'll make it again, but I have to admit I completely changed it by turning it into a crock pot recipe  Here's how I changed it:   Decreased butter to 1 T Omited Olive Oil Added 1 tsp chopped garlic Added 1 Cup water Added 1 tsp Chicken bouillon Added a splash of Tequila Added 1/2 block of cream cheese (at the END of cooking)  I added all ingredients except the cream cheese and cooked on low 6-8 hours.  The last 15 minutes I stirred in 1/2 block of cream cheese.  Stir the mixture and serve over rice or noodles!

text:
This is one of the few times I actually measured spices; usually I just ballpark it.  VERY good recipe and one I will make again.  I did add a bit of chicken broth to the lime and garlic, maybe 1/4 cup and let it simmer an additional 10 minutes or so.  I also sliced the breasts into medallions, placed them on a platter and poured the sauce on top.  It really permeated the meat that way.  Excellent, super easy recipe.

Just made this for dinner tonight and really enjoyed the flavors! I also sprinkled in lime zest.  Very tasty!  Definitely recommend this recipe!

userID:
3596668
Display Name:
Tonina_mdc
isPro:
False
followersCount:
4

0
madeRecipesCount:
27
favoritesCount:
243
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1024878.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
We really enjoyed this recipe, although I changed it a bit. I tripled the given spice mixture for 4 quite large breast halves and used fresh thyme and parsley (substituting tablespoons for teaspoons for all fresh herbs), along with jarred garlic instead of garlic powder. I made the spice mixture into a paste with about 2 T of lime juice.  Instead of cooking it on the stovetop, I baked the chicken into a 9"x13" pan. I coated the pan with a tablespoon of olive oil, put in the spice-coated chicken, put about a T of butter in small chunks around the chicken, and put a center-slice of lime on each chicken breast. I covered it with foil and baked it at 350F for 10 minutes; then poured a mixture of a half a cup of chicken broth, 1 T lime juice, some paprika, garlic, crushed red pepper, black pepper, and onion powder mixed together over top of it. I baked the chicken for another 30 minutes and it came out wonderfully moist and delicious, with a lovely spicy but not hyper-hot taste. I do think I may add a bit more lime juice next time, but my husband and I both really enjoyed this. There was plenty of sauce left to dress our rice and veggies!

text:
This was very tasty. I used all the dry ingredients as stated, except I increased the garlic to 1 teaspoon (total), and squeezed in the juice of two limes. Then I marinated the chicken breasts in the lime and spice mixture for the day and threw it on the grill. It was delicious! Thanks for the submission.

text:
It was delicious. I doubled the amount of pepper and cayenne pepper and it was great. Also when I was finished browning the chicken, I removed it and added a tbs. or so of flour and 3 tbs chicken broth. I blended it and then added the chicken, poured half the lime juice on it, added the garlic, and then when i turned the chicken added more lime juice. I also added Tequila toward the end of the cooking time. All that produced a delicious chicken with its own gravy. mmm!

The only thing I changed was to cut the cayenne pepper in half as I have kids and didn't want it to be spicy for them. This was so good and so easy a 3 year old could do it, no really my daughter (almost 3) made this I measured the spices she pounded the chicken and rubbed in the spices and poured the lime juice in and sprinkled the garlic. It was delish. My husband dint care for it as much, said it had to much lime and while I think he's crazy next time I'll do his in a separate pan with just a couple shakes of lime juice.

text:
Great recipe as-written! Followed everything exactly and the flavors of the spices were wonderful together. Definitely don't skip the step with butter/olive oil: I've found this step to be critical for the flavors to really come through...let it foam up a little, then add chicken. Yum! Served with couscous and avocado--which was awesome! Oh, and a side of green beans. :)

This recipe was excellent! It turned out a lot better than I thought it would. Here are the few things I tweaked: 1) doubled all the spices (except salt) because I like spice 2) Doubled the butter for extra sauce 3) Added mushrooms & cut asparagus right before adding the lime juice & garlic 4) Added red pepper flakes to the sauce (~1 tbsp) 5) Cooked covered for the last 5 minutes for a really moist chicken dish! Delicious! Will make often.

region:

country:
None
text:
This was pretty tasty. I was tired of chicken, so I tried it with pork chops- very good. I rubbed the pork with the spices first. Next, mixed the oil, lime juice, melted butter and second amount of garlic powder in a glass 9x9 baking pan, added the pork, coating both sides in the sauce, covered the pan with foil and baked for 30 minutes. The pork was very tender and the flavour had just the right balance between tangy and spicy. This would be excellent on the grill - pork or chicken and vegetable kabobs in this mixture of spices and the lime/garlic/butter basting sauce. Excellent recipe. UPDATE: Couldn't get limes at the store and used lemon juice instead. Still pretty tasty. I've made this many times and it always gets favourable reviews.

text:
Amazing!!!  This recipe is awesome.  The chicken always turns out moist (if cooked according to directions in recipe, and not on too high a heat) and I have found that chili powder can be substituted for the spicy spices, which I don't seem to ever have on hand, and lemon juice can be substituted for the the lime with similar results. Another thing that tastes great is substituting 1 fresh, minced garlic clove for the garlic powder in the sauce poured over at the end, but not mixed with the other powdered spices. It gives a nice kick.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm updating my review and giving this recipe 5* instead of the original 4*. Here's the secret... For more sauce I just added more of the butter, oil, and lime juice. Add an extra half of whatever it calls for (ex. 2tbs butter becomes 3tbs). I also DOUBLED ALL OF THE SPICES cause I like loads of flavor in every bite. Also, use smaller chicken breasts. ONLY FOLLOW THESE ADDITIONS IF YOU WANT A FLAVOR EXPLOSION!!! OLD REVIEW!I thought it was great, and so did my family. I don't normally make chicken because it doesn't seem to hold flavor well, but this was very tasty. I added more lime juice than recommended because I always like more sauce than normal. I wouldn't really call what's left in the pan sauce though. It's more like drippings. So, for those of you sauce fans like myself, don't be fooled. I used maybe 1/2 TBS more lime juice and it just made it more citrus-y. It was good none the less. I'd also recommend using smaller/thinner chicken breasts for more surface area for the spices. If you do go smaller remember to COOK IT LESS. Matter of fact, I'd cook the larger peices a couple minutes less than in the recipe also. Happy cooking!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Because I was short on time and had semi-frozen chicken breasts, I opted to slice the chicken in thin strips so it would thaw quicker.  Per the suggestion of other reviewers I doubled the spice mixture (with a little extra cayenne pepper because I like things spicy!) and rubbed the spice mixture into the raw chicken strips.  I followed the rest of the recipe pretty much as directed except with a little less butter and less garlic at the end.  I served the chicken in soft tortillas with taco fixings (cheese, sour cream, lettuce, etc.)  These were very good!  Personally, I just ate the meat by itself with a salad.  Yummmm!  This was a very quick, easy supper that was enjoyed by all.  I'll definitely make this again.  I also like the fact that I always have these ingredients on hand.  If you like a tangier lime (less spicy) flavor, try the Lime Chicken Tacos also on this site.  They are similar and also very good.  Thanks C. Perez for a quick, easy, great-tasting recipe!

I followed the recipe except for adding only 1/8th of a tsp. of cayenne (I didn't want it to be so spicy that my kids wouldn't eat it).  I also used boneless, skinless chicken thighs, which I would not recommend.  I think the recipe would definately be better with chicken breast strips.  I also used the remaining "sauce" (more like seasoned oil) over rice and asparagus which I also wouldn't recommend.  It made everything taste too limey.  But, overall I think this is a good recipe.  I might make this again in the summer with a green salad.

text:
Very simple and very flavorful!  I am a little paranoid about undercooked chicken, so I followed the recipe's instructions for cooking the chicken stovetop, and then put them in a baking dish (topped off with the pan drippings and covered with tin foil) and baked them at 375 for about 20 minutes.  It was the most tender and moist chicken I've had in a really long time.  I will definitely make this again!!!

text:
Excellent recipe!  I left out the cayenne and the parsley because I didn't have them, and added lime zest to the spice mixture.  I only used one lime, so I don't think it made 3 T of juice, but the zest made up for it.  I also used 6 chicken tender strips rather than the breasts (I was only cooking for 2 people) - I don't think the spice mixture would have been enough to coat 4 breasts though.  Turned out great and was very easy!  I served with Lemon Tabouli and white wine.

text:
Delicious!  I made a few changes to suit my tastes and what I had in my spice cabinet.  Instead of cayenne, I used chili powder.  I doubled the onion powder to 1/4 tsp, and I omitted the thyme.

I also made this recipe once for my mom's low sodium, high protein diet by just decreasing the salt to 1/8 tsp.  It was just as good!

Edit 10-25-2005: I made this chicken recipe again when I went camping over the weekend.  Made the spice rub, put it on the chicken, and froze chicken ahead of time.  By the time we set up camp, chicken was thawed.  I put each thawed chicken breast into a foil pouch with the juice of 1 lime.  It's definitely better cooked on the stove, but still turned out great over a campfire.

text:
ABSOLUTELY FABULOUS!!  I cut my chicken into thin strips and used the recipe as the chicken for fajitas.  No lie--after a few bites, everyone pulled the chicken out of the fajitas and ate it with their forks, then just dove into the big bowl holding all the cooked chicken and ate away.  Forget the fajitas!  Let's concentrate on the chicken!  I added green pepper and onion strips since I was using it as fajitas but did not marinate the vegetables: just added them during cooking.  This is easily the BEST chicken recipe I have gotten from this site.  Everyone I served this to just raved and all went home with recipes.  Needless to say, I will not disguise the chicken with fajita accompaniments next time and we'll just eat it as the recipe states.  I didn't measure my lime juice--just added the juice from one lime.  I wouldn't recommend any changes.  YUM!  I'm serving it again tonight to a different group of friends/family!!
Review:
Rating:

dateLastModified:
2004-06-08T23:01:55.73
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
835962
Display Name:
ASHLYNNS MOMMY
isPro:
False
followersCount:
5
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
113
favoritesCount:
697
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/18.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent dish, goes great over buttered rice. Be warned, though, it is spicy! If you don't care for hot food, be sure to reduce the amount of cayenne. I substituted the plain salt for seasoned salt, which added a wonderful flavor. I also omitted the thyme as I don't care for it, and instead of adding extra garlic powder with the lime juice, I threw in some minced fresh garlic. My only complaint was that the spices burned onto the bottom of the skillet before the chicken was done, which gave it a rather unappetizing brown color. With that presentation, I wouldn't serve it to company, but my family loved it. When I make it again, I will experiment with the prep method to see if I can make it a little more appealing to the eye. P.S. It is also good for leftovers the next day! I ate mine thinly sliced over salad greens, and made a chicken quesadilla for my daughter. YUMMY!

text:
So easy, yet so good.  You don't even really need the lime, and improvising on the spices is definitely possible as I was missing onion powder and it still came out great with minced onion instead.  Just be careful not to double up on the ingredients or you will end up with very spicy chicken.  I recommend chicken THIGHS instead of breasts for this recipe as they are much more tender.  I'm going to make this over and over as it's one of those very very very easy recipes.  I think I'll just bottle up the spice and keep it on hand.

only 4 stars because its not like food that id be drooling for. i reserve 5 stars for the best.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is a staple in our household - with some changes:
First, we LOVE spicy - so to "knock it up a notch" do the following:
•	Keep the amount of salt the same as in the original, but x4 (minimally) the amount of each of the other spices. (Note: we use thyme powder, not dried thyme)
•	Don’t “sprinkle” the spice mixture… essentially bread the chicken with the spices.
•	Add ¾ cup of chicken broth when adding in the lime juice.
Enjoy!

This recipe is a family favorite! I've been making this for 2-3 years. I use thighs instead of breasts. It works equally well whether the thighs are bone-in or boneless - just change the timing accordingly. It's easy, quick, and delicious! What more can you ask for? ;-) And in the unlikely case there are leftovers, they're wonderful cut up and tossed into a spring salad - it just adds that extra bit of zing to the salad.

text:
Delish! I don't think I need to say more. 

Oh no, wait I do. I'm very selective in what I make. I use this site for recipes when I've run out of ideas myself...I do have a Culinary Degree, however, I also have MS. There are times I walk into the kitchen to cook and can't remember how to do something as simple as a pot roast.

This site is a Godsend for me. I'm always careful to follow every recipe EXACTLY as it's written the first time I make something. I then will make notes on different things that I maybe didn't like and try it a tad different the next time around. 

I've read many reviews on here. And I've got to say that I'm somewhat disappointed when people change it and then don't give the rating it really deserves. You can't give an honest rating when you change it the first time you've cooked it. Just keep that in mind when reviewing. 

Okay, I'm done.

This was fantastic!  I usually don't review because my style of cooking means I change so much of a recipe, and this one was no exception, but I want to give props to recipes that are so adaptable and still come out amazing.  I had some boneless/skinless thighs that I needed a marinade for and this recipe turned out to be perfect.  I omitted the butter, used fresh garlic, added a few squirts of Sriracha and a couple tablespoons of tequila to bring up the liquid content. Marinaded for about an hour before grilling.  Wonderful flavor and so moist and tender.

The flavor of the spices is good and goes together well.  I am slow cooking this for tomorrow. Ps one teaspoon garlic powder was enough when doubling the amount.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I was planning to make several chicken breast halves, cooking them quickly at 450F in the oven, so I adapted this recipe to use that method for a couple of the breast halves. (I put four other breast halves in a different pan, using a plainer recipe.) Next time I'm cooking a smaller quantity of chicken, I'll try this recipe on the stovetop according to recipe instructions and see what difference it makes. I pounded the breast halves flat with an iron skillet, and brined them before cooking. Apart from that I made the recipe as written. The chicken came out juicy and very delicious! It went well with mashed sweet potato and roasted brussels sprouts. Tonight for dinner, I warmed the leftovers with cooked brown rice, a baby spinach/baby kale mix, and a few grape tomatoes, and it was again delicious. (I made a bit of extra sauce by adding chicken broth, garlic, and lime juice to what I had left over, and added a bit of flour to thicken.)  Recipe highly recommended, if you like lime juice, as I do.

text:
Made this to go with Cuban black beans.  Mixed 4x the amount of dry spices and rubbed onto flattened chicken.  Zested a lime on top of  spiced chicken.   Let chicken rest in a pan in the fridge overnight, covered.  Squeezed lime juice over chicken and cooked at 350 for about an hour.  Moist, juicy and delicious!  Lower calorie than original recipe.  Will make again as a simple and flavorful meat main.

text:
We absolutely Love this chicken recipe. What an interesting and authentic twist on spice combining. It’s super easy to prepare. I added the spices to a large ziplock bag to combine. I then put good quality free range boneless skinless chicken breasts into the bag, zipped it up and moved it around enough to coat the spices all over each piece. I put in the fridge and let marinade for 6-8 hours, moving the chicken around a bit every 2-3 hours.

text:
Delicious chicken and pretty easy to make as well. You can eyeball the spices because a  lot of it comes off in the initial rub down. I ended up adding more paprika and cayenne after putting the chicken in the pan to get more bright red color.  I followed other reviewers' suggestions to dredge the chicken in flour, but did not pound or flatten the breast pieces like I wanted to. It didn't matter, as the chicken managed to cook evenly and thoroughly per the recipes instructions (+1-2 minutes a side and +2 mins during the final cook).
