I pounded the chicken breasts , seasoned one side and rolled a good amount of goat cheese into the breasts.  The goat cheese was strong enough to stand up to the spices for a wonderfully rich and balanced flavor.  I increased the blended spice mix and cut the final garlic dusting in half.  Also added half a cup of chicken stock for the sauce.  Some of the goat cheese melts into the sauce for an an amazing flavor and consistency!  My wife is quite the food critic and she complemente the dish multiple times throuout the meal.  We both agreed that this dish will be a regular in our household.

userID:

Display Name:
kazzed
isPro:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674158.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
4 stars as-is.  The spice rub is great, but the technique needs a bit of tweaking:  Here's how I made it a 5-star recipe:  Rub the chicken with the spices and then cook the chicken in a stainless steel or cast-iron skillet, something that will leave behind a good amount of fond.  Remove the chicken but keep the heat on, mince a few cloves of garlic and add it to the skillet, stir for about 20-30 seconds.  De-glaze the skillet with somewhere between 1/2 to 1 cup chicken stock, add the juice of 1/2 lime (per two chicken breasts), and as others have suggested, a splash of tequila.  Reduce the stock, add butter, and stir.  Spoon this garlic-lime-tequila-butter pan sauce over the chicken.  Serve!
Review:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614248.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My husband and I enjoyed this dish very much - it 's quite tasty and does not take alot of time to make. Based on comments from other reviewers, at the sauce step (when you are supposed to add the garlic powder and lime), I added chicken broth and garlic paste (about a tablespoon - less which makes it pretty garlicky), which comes in a tube ( I used the Amore brand).

I did use garlic powder in the seasoning mix that is sprinkled on the chicken. Also, I made more seasoning mix than called for because reviewers commented that the recipe does not make enough to cover the chicken, which turned  out to be a good move.

We sliced the chicken against the grain and made soft chicken tacos with lettuce,  chopped tomatoes, minced red onion and fresh cilantro, and drizzled the sauce on top. Delish - I would definitely make this again!

Used 2 breasts cut in half and pounded to even out. Used twice as much spices- rubbed both sides and marinated in fridge all afternoon. Went light on the dried thyme- personal preference. This spice rub was excellent and we all loved it. Used 3 plus maybe a little more T fresh lime juice and thought it was over powering but maybe because I only used 2 breasts? There was no juice so I had to add a little chicken stock. I think with some doctoring the sauce could be excellent. I may even just air fry the chicken next try. Lots of potential with this base as a start thanks for the recipe

I made this as is! I didn't need to cook my chicken as long since it was quite thin, I didn't want it to dry out. The only issue I had was the amount of salt. text:
The flavor was really great, however I feel like it may have worked better as a marinade? 

The chicken turned out dry  (Probably due to me not being the best cook ) so maybe increasing the serving of spices/oils and treating it as a marinade would have helped me. 

At the end of it, the sauce reduced down too much, so I ended up adding more oil and cutting up the chicken into small chunks. Maybe the chicken breasts I used were too thick? 

I altered things a bit, using Italian seasoning instead of just parsley. Either way, the chicken's flavor was off the charts, and I'd totally try making it again! :D

I thought the extra garlic powder at the end might be overpowering, so I included it in the original rub instead. My grocer sells giant mutant chicken breasts -- like, a pound each -- so I cut them in half as if to butterfly them. After reading all the reviews, I started off by doubling all the spices and using fresh garlic and onion instead of powdered. Display Name:
Kyle Rother

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674153.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made zero substitutions. I'll start with the pros:

Chicken came out very juicy at the recommended cook time. I did spend pretty much the entire time after the first flip basting the chicken, though. The lime also adds some incredible flavor, never thought about using lime during the cooking process for chicken like this. Quite tasty. 

Cons: While the chicken itself is juicy and whatnot, the spices weren't all there. The amount of salt was fine, but in the future I think I would add more pepper and ABSOLUTELY more cayenne/paprika. I might have even doubled both of those amounts, if not tripled the cayenne. I was really hoping for some nice heat on the chicken but none of it came through, disappointing on that front. 

I served this dish alongside some bacon maple Brussels sprouts and it was an excellent pairing. EDIT: I accidentally lied, I did make one change. The garlic powder added at the end I halved because 2 teaspoons there is just way too much. The garlic came through without overpowering the dish, like others here are saying.

5

I made this with chicken quarters so decided to bake it instead. Squeezed the lime directly on the chicken, left the lime rinds in the pan, and covered it with foil with the melted butter and olive oil covering the bottom of the pan. Baked for 45 minutes on 450 and then broiled for 10 minutes to crisp up the skin. Delicious!

country:
None
text:
This is EXCELLENT !! An instant easy favorite, going right into the recipe book!

Made it twice - the first time I followed the recipe exactly, the second time I made 3 adjustments that turned this good recipe into a stellar one. On the second round, I added 1/3c chicken broth and TRIPLED the spices, while completely omitting the garlic powder at the end. 

All of those were suggested by other users, and seriously, I love this stuff ! The chicken was wonderfully moist and there was plenty of sauce to toss over my rice and veggies, giving those a tasty kick !

Following the recipe exactly left the chicken a teeny bit dry, and there was barely enough of the spice mix for two medium chicken breasts ! Tripling the spices gave me enough for four chicken breasts.

I doubled most of the spices and the lime juice. (Actually, just juiced 5 little limes.) Used one clove fresh garlic instead of powder, and frozen parsley instead of dried. And, since I had no chicken broth handy, I added about 1/3 cup of regular sherry. Afterward, I wished I had added the sherry first, boiled it down a bit, and then added the lime juice. userID:
8976816
Display Name:
BobTheTinkerer
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677176.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The spices in this recipe are just fantastic. In my case, I was looking for a spicy lime chicken recipe for quesadillas, and this worked out perfectly. Needless to say, I didn’t need to worry about sauce, so I skipped out on some of the suggestions about adding broth.

But, I will say that it turned out a bit too salty for our tastes. And we don’t shrink back from salt here, so that’s saying something. I’m going to cut the salt in half for the next batch, which will probably be soon. The rest of the flavors, and especially the sour lime, were off-the-charts good!

Honestly, I think this turned out like very good blackened chicken you might get at a restaurant. It would be excellent on a salad. One of the reasons I like this recipe so much is that it lets me make chicken that is extremely versatile (thinly sliced for a hot sandwich, with melted mozzarella?).

In my case, I did make a couple changes. We use avocado oil for all our heated oil cooking needs, so that was used with the butter instead. I also used only one pack of two chicken breasts from Costco, each cut in half the long way. Lastly, we like it spicy, so we quadrupled the amount of cayenne pepper. We’ll probably go 6X on the next run (1-1/2 tsp). Also, skipped out on the garlic powder at the finish.

Everything else I followed to the letter. Though, I did double the recipe so I could coat both sides of each slice of chicken. It ended up being not quite enough, so I may triple it next time.

The quesadillas turned o

5

text:
This is great! Just be forewarned that if you're using really large chicken breasts, you'll need to double the amount of spice rub and adjust the cooking time. I usually buy organic breasts, which tend to be smaller, but had to use conventional this time. I could only fit two per pan! Even after pounding them flat, they needed 10 minutes in the oven at 350 after browning on each side. Then I took them out and finished the sauce on the stove. They were juicy and flavorful with a nice crust.

I'm rating this 4 but my hubby would say 5.  I doubled the spices as a lot of reviewers did but I found it way to spicy. text:
This wasn't bad, and it kept us full for dinner.  There wasn't really enough spice rub, and it wasn't particularly spicy.  We weren't expecting a fire alarm, but the spice was barely perceptible.

We made the recipe pretty much as is, though added minced garlic at the end rather than powdered.

Other problem was maybe specify how much chicken?  Our breasts were likely too large because they were quite dry by the time it reached an appropriate cooking temperature, so it's possible a stint in the oven or a covered dish might retain some moisture.

But a quick and relatively enjoyable weeknight meal.

I make this all the time and it never disappoints! If you want to keep it healthier and omit the butter, it's just as good. city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Me and my family loved this dish!  Here is my suggestion.  Thaw the chicken breasts just until they can be cut, then half them crosswise.  Fillet each of the pieces into four thin slices and pound them between Press n Seal sheets on a cutting board to make them extra tender.  Other than this filleting  technique I followed the recipe just as written with this one exception.  After the chicken was cooked I mixed a small amount of heavy cream into the drippings in the skillet, turned the chicken to coat evenly then served with buttered pasta noodles sprinkled with Parmesan cheese.  DELICIOUS!  This recipe is a keeper!

text:
This recipe is sensational! I usually frown on people talking about their alterations. However, in this case I must make an exception. Because I use the spices and do this in the oven. And it is super easy! Just spray your glass baking dish with a little spray oil. Put your chicken breasts in. Season them on both sides. Top with a little spray oil. And bake at 350 until they reach 165 F temperature.   Depending on the size of the breasts – 20 to 35 minutes. Because I use small breasts, I do not flatten them.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was AMAZING! We used 4 chicken breasts (about 2lb) so we took the advice from others who made this recipe and DOUBLED the seasoning... then allowed the chicken to marinade from 9am until 5pm. 

For the second step, we used fresh garlic instead of garlic powder... and we used vegan butter instead of regular (because someone in the family can't have dairy). Using another reviewer's tip, we also added a splash of tequila - always a good thing! 

Cooked to the right temp, this chicken was so flavorful and juicy. Every member of the family gobbled it up and asked for more. One last note I'd like to share - another reviewer suggested adding a bag of spinach into the leftover sauce (after plating the chicken)... and good gracious! That was the best spinach anyone had eaten in quite a well. 

All in all - what a hit! We will definitely make this again soon.

text:
This one is definitely a keeper!  We read the reviews first and made a few changes. We pounded the chicken breasts so they were the same thickness. We doubled the seasoning and let the chicken marinade in the seasoning for a couple of hours. After sauteing the chicken breasts as directed, we mixed the lime juice with half a cup of chicken broth and a few cloves of minced garlic. We also added a splash of tequila and a splash of margarita mix for good measure! The chicken was so tender and absolutely delicious. We served it with roast potatoes and vegetables. Fantastic!!

text:
This chicken was so good! My husband and I thoroughly enjoyed this recipe. I used chicken thighs and actually doubled the seasoning because I was reading other comments saying that it wouldn't be enough for all four chicken thighs. I flipped the chicken every three minutes for 12 minutes before i put in the lime to prevent it from getting too dark in one area. I served it with a side of Mexican rice, steamed broccoli, and corn. All in all, it was extremely easy to make and super quick. Made for great dinner.

I just did a couple of things different, I doubled the rub and I filleted the chicken breasts and cut those in half for smaller pieces.  Then I sautéed some peppers and onions before I fried the chicken, and set those aside.  During the last 5 mins of the chicken cooking I added the peppers back to the pan and covered the pan.  Served over brown rice and a wedge of fresh lime.   This recipe was very, very good and will make again!

text:
Great base to build around. Used a little bit of flour/maybe 1/8 cup and mixed the spices(chipotle chili powder in lieu of cayenne) in with it. Very thin layer around the chicken but came out awesome. I used fresh onions and garlic instead of the suggested powders. Onions were added towards the end with the garlic, not coated prior. I squeezed 3 limes, next time would use just 2 but it was really good.  Only used 2 breasts(1.25 lbs) but kept the spices the same if not added a little more. 

Will be making this again...oh and I did try the splash of tequila someone else had posted in their review...EXCELLENT! Might have sprinkled in too much but can peel it back a little next batch.  Thank You for sharing the recipe, best wishes to you.

text:
DELICIOUS!! I made some modifications. I used chili powder rather than cayenne pepper (almost the same thing) I also made 5 pieces of chicken so I made more of the spice mix and made sure each piece was well seasoned. I squeezed one and a half limes over the chicken after it was cooked and deglazed the pan using some chicken broth (just poor it in the pan with the chicken in it and all). It helped make a sauce. As I let it simmer for a little bit, I added some fresh minced garlic and just a sprinkle (maybe 1/4 teaspoon) of garlic powder. Waited until the sauce thickened and ate it up! Was freaking amazing. I haven't seen my caveman of a husband eat that fast in a while! Served it with fire roasted corn (from a can) and some black beans! (And sliced avo and jals) AMAZING.

My family loved this dish which is important for families that eat chicken as a regular dish each week.  It takes a bit of time to prepare so I doubled the recipe to have leftovers for a family of 4.  It's just as good 1-2 days later as it is on the first night.  Thumbs up from a cook who works a full week but still needs to have flavorful easy to prepare meals to mix-up economical dishes.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
made as close as i could to the recipe but didn't have garlic powder so i used garlic salt, also added dried cilantro.  I quadrupled the spices and glad i did... i had 5 medium sized chicken breasts and flattened them a bit, and the spice amount was perfect.  I also only had realemon juice on hand so used it instead of lime juice, and also added 1/4 cup chicken broth at the end.  I didn't add any more garlic salt at the end, just the broth and lemon juice.  I can't believe my boys loved it, and they don't like ANYTHING.  It was a bit saltier than i would have liked but I'm sure it was due to the garlic salt (I didn't add add the salt called for in the recipe).  This was wonderful and will be added into my rotation!

I followed the recipe pretty closely but listened to previous reviewers and doubled the spices except for the garlic powder. I threw in some fresh minced garlic at the end when I added the lime juice (I just squeezed two limes, didn't bother to measure the amount). This chicken is DELICIOUS. I kept eating pieces straight out of the skillet while it was finishing up cooking. I added in some black beans at the end to warm them up, and we had burritos with the chicken & beans, some rice, salsa, avocado, and sliced onion. This is going to be a new staple at our house!

text:
Delicious! I followed the suggestions of other reviewers and doubled the spices. I used bone in chicken breasts which took forever to cook. If you have limited time ... use boneless. When the chicken was done, I removed from pan and added the lime juice, garlic powder and 1/2 cup chicken broth to pan drippings. The chicken was returned to the pan and cooked, per directions until done. My husband was skeptical because he is not a citrus lover. But he had seconds .... an excellent indicator of a good meal! I will make again.

This is a very tasty recipe.The chicken was very juicy! The only changes  I made were, I took 2 larges chicken breasts and cut them in half  & at the end I  added  the garlic by pinches, (not the 3 Tablespoons the recipe calls for) Other than that  I stuck to the recipe. If  I would make four large chicken breasts I would double the seasonings. Even my (taste tester) husband  liked this recipe.  He liked the smell of the spices when I was mixing them together & he said the chicken was juicy, flavorful , not too spicy the way I like it.

text:
I've been making this for several years, and it's still my son's favorite.  I just add the lime juice and everything together (I use lots of fresh minced garlic instead of garlic powder), then coat the chicken and maybe even marinate for a few hours.   When the chicken is finished cooking in the pan, I remove it and make a small amount of gravy using chicken broth and water/cornstarch.  It's great with the drippings still in the pan!

text:
Good basic recipe but can be much better. Double the amount of the spices and brine the chicken breasts for at least 2 hours before cooking. The meat will be much more tender and juicy after the brining. Good quick recipe with the changes I suggested. Serve with white rice cooked in beef consommé and broccolini , steamed, coated with a vinaigrette of olive oil and balsamic vinegar.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614242.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was simply amazing! The combination of the spices just work and produce this delicious chicken that looks and tastes like those in 5 star restaurants.  I followed the recipe with a couple of modifications as per other readers' suggestions.  After rubbing the spices all over, I put them in a zip lock bag and let it sit in the fridge for a couple of hours which absorbed the flavors even more.  After taking them out of the fridge  I let them rest on the counter while I prepared the side dishes.  I also used 2 large cloves of fresh garlic pressed instead of the garlic powder and added 1/2 cup of chicken stock to the pan. I had roasted a spaghetti squash for the side dish and after removing the chicken from the pan I tossed the squash in the wonderful glaze which added such flavor to the squash I could not stop eating it!  Thank you so much for this quick and tasty recipe.  I will make it again and again!

country:
None
text:
Make sure you get the breast with the rib meat attached, makes for a juicier end result. This is a thicker cut, so after the first 3 -4 minutes, cover to retain moisture and promote more thourough cooking. Didn't have limes, used lemon instead. Also added anout 50% more butter than recipe called for. Also added Chili powder, threw in some lemon slices to cook in juices in pan, adding to the flavor of "spooning" juice. Last two minutes topped with more lemon slices. Came out awesome! Nice crust outside, flavorful and juicy!

I would definitely cut the salt to 1/4 of a tsp. and increase other spices to make up the difference. Also, when you sprinkle it on, this recipe is for a light sprinkling. If you want more spice on your chicken, you might had to double the recipe. Unfortunately, the salt was way to much for my family and they don't want me to make this again, but with some tweeking, it could be really good!

text:
This was delicious! Didn't have onion powder, cayenne pepper, or paprika, so left those off. Also left out thyme. Had to make more of the rub, but I was cooking six chicken breasts, not four.  Guesstimated the amount of lime juice, (I just used the juice of an entire lime), and I sliced the chicken into strips partway through cooking to help them cook faster. I also doubled the amount of garlic powder in the rub, so didn't add any afterwards with the lime juice. Came out beautifully, received lots of compliments from family, and will definitely make again! Thanks! :-D

text:
I followed recommendations of others.  I used chicken tenderloins and pounded them.  I used 1/4 t.  of all spices.  I seared the chicken until browned; removed from skillet.  I added 2 minced garlic cloves (instead of garlic powder) and sauteed until golden.  Then I added  1/2 c. chicken broth and lime juice and returned the chicken to the skillet, simmering about 7 min.  My son declared that this was the best chicken I ever made!  Obviously, I'll make it again.

I love this recipe!  It's become one of my regulars because it's easy and delicious.  I let the spices set for about 20 minutes before I start cooking the chicken.  I also took the advice of another commenter and add 1/4 cup chicken broth to create a pan sauce and I use minced garlic instead of garlic power (~ 2 tsp) for the step while the chicken is cooking.

text:
I made twice as much of the spice mix (didn't double the salt, cut out the garlic powder, as I don't like garlic powder). Pounded the chicken breasts down a bit. Browned the chicken in olive oil-butter mixture, then added 2/3 cup of chicken broth, and 3 large cloves of garlic, crushed. Cooked the chicken, then added the lime at the last minute. Served with rice. 

Delicious.

text:
I couldn't bring myself to add 2 tsp of garlic powder with the lime at the end, so I gave it a heavy dusting. Very quick to prepare and my spice rack is readily available so it was not inconvenient to me to create the spice mixture.  We used skinless, boneless thighs as that us what we had.  The flavor was good, but next time I will try additional cayenne for more kick, and go a little lighter on the lime juice, or maybe go with crushed garlic rather  than powder. Good recipe to tweak to suit your taste. Thank you for sharing!

country:
None
text:
The whole family liked chicken prepared this way.  I pounded the pieces to a uniform thickness, and I placed the combined seasonings in an empty spice jar to sprinkle evenly over each piece.  I wonder how this would be with chili powder instead of cayenne, and Mexican oregano instead of thyme?  Think I'll try it like that, next time, because the cayenne adds heat, but not much flavor.  I chose not to use the extra garlic powder at the end.  I squeezed the lime over the chicken pieces, then covered and turned down the heat to low.  The pan juices were enough to coat the chicken, and we did were fine without a sauce.

text:
Fantastic chicken! I made it into a marinade and grilled it on the Weber instead of cooking it in a pan. I had to slice really thick chicken breasts in half, then 30 minutes in the marinade before grilling. It turned out flavorful and really moist, served it with rice pilaf and a salad. Thanks!

3 TBSP olive oil
6 TBSP key lime juice
1 tsp salt
1/2 tsp pepper
1/2 tsp cayenne pepper
1/2 tsp red pepper flakes
1/2 tsp paprika
2.5 tsp garlic powder
1 tsp onion powder
1/2 tsp thyme
1 tsp dried parsley

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614252.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was delicious, healthy and easy. Minor modifications...

1. brown the seasoned chicken on all sides. Remove from pan and set aside. 
2. Add 1/2 cup chopped onion and saute. Add a splash of dry white wine to deglaze pan. 
3. Then add 1/3 cup of chicken broth mixed with 1 tbsp corn starch or arrowroot starch to thicken the sauce. Add 2 tbsp. of lime juice at this point, reserving last tbsp. 
4. Return chicken to pan, lower heat and simmer until done. Add reserved lime juice to add at the end of cooking time. 

Other suggestions: you only need about a half tsp. of salt and a final sprinkle of the additional garlic powder. I decided not to add the last 2 tsp. garlic powder, and my dish had plenty of flavor.
Review:
Rating:
5

text:
I made it "as is" and enjoyed it so very much.  I did however, cook it in my microwave pressure cooker for 30 minutes.  That process forces the flavors, spices, herbs, through the meat and certainly enhances the eating pleasures.  I did add 1 cup of chicken broth because I needed a certain amount of liquid to properly pressure cook the breasts.  Next time, I will put the lime rind (from 2 limes), into the pressure cooker to magnify that flavor even more.  

Great recipe... C. Perez!  Thank you!

text:
I am having a very difficult time rating this dish. My husband HATED it (didn't eat more than two bites); however, I really liked the spices used with the chicken and the butter/oil frying method (I am actually adapting a chicken fettuccini alfredo recipe from this base). I don't know if it was the sauce coating the chicken or what. I am going to play around with this and adapt to my tastes. 

P.S. I would have rated 2 1/2 stars (as he hated and I liked)-- but I felt the easy in preparation should count for something!

text:
This was my first time sautéing chicken on the stove top, as I don't cook often. I looked for a great recipe online and came across this one. My family, including my MIL all loved this chicken! I was so pleased. I followed the original poster's recipe exactly, because I was afraid it would be an awful disaster. The one exception is that I used 3 chicken breast scallopine (from Sprouts), and instead of 4 chicken breast halves. I also rubbed the chicken with the spice mixture. The end result --it was moist and delicious. My 9 y.o. daughter said it was a little too spicy for her but she liked the chicken a lot. First time I've ever used someone else's recipe and it came out lovely.

text:
After looking at all of the reviews I made my own version of this recipe and I absolutely love it along with my family! Instead of using chicken breasts I chose cutlets and marinaded them with the exact spices above (but doubled) for 2-3 hours. Then I did everything else like the recipe said but because I was using cutlets, the cook time was reduced greatly. I did not use the broth like others suggest, and I will definently make this again! I especially love the spicyness of the dish because it kicked in later and it wasn't too hot.

text:
I doubled the spice mix just to make sure I had enough.  Glad I did as I used about 1.5 times what was called for in the recipe.  I was nervous about adding too much lime and garlic at the end; wish I would have had more lime, but I was fine I held back on the garlic.  I also found for the cooking times required, you don't necessary need to pound them that thin...maybe just the thicker parts a little.  Also, a side note, I added leftover lime to the parmesan-basil orzo I made with it and it turned out pretty good.

text:
Fabulous recipe. I made a pan gravy at the end. To do that, I added a couple Tbsp of flour and about a cup (give or take) of chicken stock. I added plenty of freshly ground black pepper and just a dash of garlic powder. I added a splash of milk a few times...total about a 1/4-1/2 cup. The gravy turned out awesome and was a nice touch to the chicken. The dish went FAST so I will have to double next time. Thanks for the recipe!

text:
The entire family enjoyed this recipe.  The spice added pizzaz to the recipe, but not so much that those who don't like spicy foods would dislike it.  I did cut the breasts into 3 or 4 pieces so that they would cook faster, or it would  have taken much more time than the recipe called for.

If one wanted to make a sauce for rice or pasta, chicken broth could be added, scraping up the bits from the pan.

The second time I made this, I grilled the chicken, brushing it with the butter/oil/lime mix as it cooked. Delicious!

text:
Good! I opted to brine my chicken breast a couple hours before I cooked it (soak in salt water mix -- 1/2 cup kosher salt to 1 quart of water; pat chicken breast dry before cooking) and skipped the salt in the seasoning. It turned out to be a bit on the salty side for the parts of the chicken that were thinner, but perfect for the center (not to mention tender and juicy!). I might reduce the salt in my next brine (1/4 cup), but otherwise would follow the recipe as is (eventually experimenting with using real onions and garlic though). Served over rice with some veggies yum yum :)

country:
None
text:
We loved this recipe! I doubled it for more servings, but I didn't double the salt. In fact, I would probably only use 1/2 t or less of salt next time. I also only had 1 T of butter left in the butter dish so I did a 1 to 2 ratio of butter to oil in the pan. I had so much chicken that I had to cook it in two batches, so when it was all cooked I poured the drippings back in the pan, set the chicken aside, and added the garlic powder and lime juice (from two whole limes) to the drippings for the sauce. Then poured the sauce over the chicken on a platter. Wow! Our friends went back for thirds! Absolutely delicious served with rice and veggies!

I LOVE this recipe!  My husband loves it too, which is even more incredible.  I follow everything exactly, except that I do not add the extra garlic powder at the end.  I felt like it would have been too much, and we love it without it anyway.  If I'm making more than about a half pound of chicken, I always make at least double the spice mixture.  I also might trying to use less butter when cooking it, as it tends to brown a little quicker with it, and it risks burning the edges of the chicken.

I love this recipe but I did change it the second time I prepared it just on how I prepared it. I went ahead and mix up my spices and add 1 teaspoon of Season All Salt to it as well. I sliced my chicken breast up where they looked like more like stir fry slices instead of whole breast for faster cooking time.  Then I put the chicken with the spice and shake it up. I fixed the butter olive oil with fresh minced garlic kind of like scampi style. Then just before I pulled it I squeased on my lime juice. My family like it better the second time because they said the chicken was spiced more evenly. This now has became our go to chicken taco recipe. Thank you for share. Last night I tried even adding the splash of tequila as one member suggested by add it with Lime juice and it was great as well.

country:
None
text:
I made this a little bit differently and it came out amazing.

I skipped the cayenne pepper since my son doesn't like spicy - then I mixed all the ingredients together - make sure the butter is softened not melted. It will form a loose shmear.

Use chicken THIGHS instead of breasts (make sure you pound them to thin them out a bit) then spread the thighs with the shmear and place and grill. I used a stove top grill pan - it came out so amazing! The lime just gives it something special. Will definitely be adding to my frequently used book.

text:
This recipe was delicious the spices were right on the money,(did not use lime juice) I used only one large organic chicken breast pounded to 1/2 inch thick cut the seasoning in half and cooked to golden brown with 2 Tbsp olive oil and 1 Tbsp butter, Then set aside to rest and added 2 Tbsp butter 2 Tbsp flour about 1/4 cup chicken broth and reduced to a pan sauce seasoned sauce with RSS and put chicken back to blend. served over rice.

text:
OH. MY. GOODNESS!!! This was a keeper, for sure. My husband was late leaving the office, and he said he had skipped lunch and was starving. I had everything ready the minute he walked in the door. A very quick, very flavorful chicken dish. I prepared it exactly as written except for taking the suggestion of some other reviewers of doubling the spice mix except the salt, and adding chicken broth to deglaze the pan. I also pounded my chicken breasts. They came out so juicy, tender, and delicious. This was phenomenal! Next time I want to try the suggestions of using fresh garlic and onion instead of dry spices. Still, as written, this is one of the best quick dishes I have ever cooked. Served with yellow Spanish rice and black beans. Hubby said to make sure this one goes in the regular rotation.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent, foolproof, chicken recipe. I found myself making this recipe so often I changed the serving size to 40 and reprinted it so I could keep a large batch of the spice mixture on hand. Having the spices already combined makes for a very fast and easy last minute dinner. I always butterfly and pound the chicken thin before adding the spices and I am very heavy handed with the rub, generously coating both sides of each piece of chicken. I serve this most often with spanish rice and sweet mexican corn cake.  Also good cut up and served wrapped in grilled totillas or on a bed of tortilla chips with salsa and melted cheese.  PERFECT with margaritas!  After three years of using AR and over 800 recipes saved, this is by far my picky eater husbands most requested recipe.  My husband even begs me to make it for company and it always receives good reviews even requests for the recipe.

text:
Very yummy! I doubled the recipe as my chicken breasts were very large. I could have laid off the spices about 1/4. Maybe mix up a full batch of spices but only put about 3/4 of the mixture on. I like spice but it was almost overkill. I did not use as much cayenne - just sprinkled a bit - to keep heat down. Nor did I sprinkle the extra garlic powder at the end - that would totally be overkill. Like another user I put 1/3 c chicken stock on with the lime juice at the end. then ladled sauce on chicken when plating. served with a homemade rice pilaf and the whole family was happy!

text:
A really easy and tasty way to spice up your chicken!  I just made this and followed the recipe adding the hints of other reviewers.  I used just two chicken breasts and pounded them to the same thickness.  Even using two breasts I had to double the spice mixture to cover both sides.  I also added 1/3 cup of chicken stock with the lime juice and basted the breasts for the last 5 minutes.  I served it with chicken rice and  drizzled the sauce over both.  It was fresh and spicy, I could really see adding it to a salad.  I will make again for sure!

text:
This is a great receipt, but the measurements in the ingredients should be doubled if you use 4 breasts. Otherwise you will only have enough seasoning for one side of the chicken. Notice it says "generously"... But if you have high blood pressure, stick with this amount. I love my food spicy so I double the ingredients, and didn't use parsley or onion powder. I instead used a real cut up onion to fry it on top of... um um um!

text:
Exceptionally easy and good!  I used boneless, skinless thighs instead of breasts because that's what I had on hand.  I probably quadrupled the recipe for the dry ingredients.  I also used about 5 limes (they were small) and served it with additional lime wedges and sliced avocado for those of us that love avocados.  My son and I both agreed that the coolness of the avocado really complemented the spiciness of the cayenne and black peppers.  I would definitely make again.  I served it with a red bean and rice mix and some prepared bean and cheese burritos topped with salsa.

Very good taste.  I did have one problem at first.  I do not have a non stick pan yet, but heavy stainless steel.  I ended up adding the butter and oil and burnt it.  I took it immediately off the heat to let it cool, cleaned it up and used spray and it still seemed like the little booger was going to stick so I cooked it a bit on both sides to sear it, and added a little water, like 1/4 c or so, and the chicken turned out so moist.  Great flavor!  A little spicy cuz I rubbed it with a double batch of spices, but had it with rice and it countered the spices for those who don't like it hot.  Thank you so much for this recipe! Used a small, minced onion instead of onion powder and fresh garlic.  Also added half a minced green pepper. https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/927526.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a good solid recipe. Quick, easy, and tasty results. I'm giving it 4 stars because it's not mind-blowingly amazing, but definitely a keeper in my recipe rotation. I used some dried cilantro instead of thyme because I was out. I nearly doubled the cayenne pepper because we love spice in my house! I also used 1/2 lime, 1/2 lemon juice because I ran out of lime juice. I doubled the spices as suggested, because I cut up my chicken breasts (more surface area to cover = more spices needed). I also added some broth at the end to get the brown bits up and whisked in a little corn starch to make a sauce. It was quick, tasty and satisfying. Will make again.

text:
I enjoyed this a lot.  Per other reviews I doubled the spice mixture (and still barely had enough for 4 breasts) except for the salt.  Increased the cayenne and garlic powder a bit.  I also pounded the breasts to be a bit thinner.  I just sprinkled the breasts with a bit of garlic powder instead of using the full 2 teaspoons.  Added a few tablespoons of chicken broth to the sauce as well.
Good flavors and spice level, not a whole lot of lime taste.  Would definitely make again.

text:
Awesome!  A couple of changes - I added all of the garlic to the rub mixture and increased the thyme & parsley to 1 Tbls each.  I also added about 1 Tsp of cayenne and left the onion powder out.  I seared the seasoned chicken in a dutch oven with just the olive oil and then I added the juice of two limes to finish cooking.  Added the butter right at the end to give a little body to the pan drippings and served over a creamy lime risotto.

This is my first review, and if I could give this more stars I would! My husband raved about the flavor. I used this to make pork fajitas with thinly sliced pork loin. The only thing I added was a teaspoon of grated lime zest to the dry ingredients, with I then used as a dry marinade-I put the sliced pork into a zipper bag with the dry ingredients,shook to distribute, and fridged it for 2 hours, then did a quick saute to brown. WOWWOWWOW!!! I'm going to do this for my dad-in-law's birthday picnic this summer with the chicken. FANTASTIC, C.Perez, thank you!!

text:
I made this tonight, along with Baja Stuffed Potatoes also on this site, for dinner.  It was a quick and easy recipe that did not need alot of babysitting while I was fixing the other recipe.  My husband and I really liked it although I felt it was a little salty - I used kosher salt, which made have made a difference so I will adjust for next time.  Great flavors though.  I also flattened the chicken breast and then split in two to make smaller portions that would cook up a little faster and go a little further.  Definitely a keeper!

I used fresh garlic and minced onion & rubbed all the spices on the chicken as directed. Then, I baked the chicken in the oven for 25 minutes at 350, then took it out and drizzled lime juice all over. Then, I returned it to the oven to continue cooking at 350 for about 8 minutes. It was great!

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was fabulous! I changed it a little. I used twice the seasonings except left out the parsley. I sliced the 4 chicken breasts like fajita meat, and used the seasoning as a rub. I pre-coooked an onion in butter that I had wedged then took it out and set it aside, then added the oil to the pan and cooked the meat. When it was almost finished I added one can of Rotel and a handful of fresh cilantro.  After that had cooked down (3 min. maybe) and the meat was done I added one tsp of garlic powder and 3 Tsp. lime juice and threw back in the onions. Served in a warm tortilla. Our foreign exchange student from Mexico said it looked like something his mother would serve. He loved it. Has a good kick without being too hot.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2567758.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great with changes:  Mince together onion, garlic, and jalapeno and add to dry rub--with more cayenne than indicated.   Use bone-in/skin-on breasts and rub mixture under and on top of skin.  Broil to crisp skin (very important).  Sautee in heavy cast iron skillet in butter and olive oil until done.   Remove chicken.  Deglaze pan with lime juice.  Add garlic powder and pour over chicken.  These changes make this a five-star recipe.

country:
None
text:
This was really, really good. I made the recipe exactly as directed except that I used lemon juice instead of lime juice (I thought I had some lime juice in the fridge, but I was wrong). The spices made this really flavorful. I found that it took much longer to cook the chicken than the recipe had indicated, and by the time I got my chicken to the right temperature it had gotten a bit dry. If I make this again (and I plan to), I will probably pound the chicken to make it a bit thinner (and uniform in thickness) so that it cooks faster and hopefully doesn't dry out as much. The sauce was very good over rice.

text:
This was a really good recipe.  I made double the amount of chicken breasts, and didn't really measure out the spices.  All I know is that I doubled the spices for the first four, ran out and then made my own concoction.  I used fresh garlic, fresh onions as well as the powders.  I fried in butter for quite awhile and added some chicken broth too. I wasn't satisfied they were cooked so threw them into the oven at 350 for about 10 minutes.  Oh, and I put a lot of garlic powder on them before that.  They turned out perfectly and the flavor was great.  I served the chicken with some brown rice and corn on the cob and my husband raved about it.  This is a keeper.

text:
This is one of the few recipes my husband has asked me to make time and again.  I usually use chicken breast tenders (or cut chicken breasts into smaller pieces) to maximize the seasoning to chicken ratio.  I coat them in the spices and pan fry (I just eyeball the necessary amount of butter and oil) and add the juice from one lime.  Easy, quick and can play around with the spices to make it to your liking.

text:
One of our favorite chicken recipes! I use thighs instead of breasts and put the spice mixture both on the outside of the chicken and under the skin. Because of this I usually quadruple the spices and find I have just enough spice to generously coat six thighs.  I also wait and add the butter at the end so the chicken doesn't get overly brown during cooking.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/290341.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My husband and I love this dish - great with rice and steamed veggies. The spices are tedious to prepare every time so I made a 32 serving batch of just the spices and dispense as needed. Huge time saver, removes the "fussy" from this tasty recipe. I think tenderizing the chicken to an even thickness made the biggest difference along with cooking at a slightly lower temperature. Previous higher temp attempts led to calling this dish Chicken Asphyxia - so much hot oil in the air we were choking and had to open all the windows. Even after an experience like that I still get requests :)

Hmmmmm. Made this for dinner tonight. While my bf and I both liked it, we didn't LOVE it. It did smell great while sauteeing though.... text:
My husband and I love this dish and never get tired of it.  I followed the advice of others and doubled the butter/olive oil.  Also, I usually use a little less than the called for lime juice.  3 T. was a little overpowering for us.  I also found that if you cook the lime juice mix. more than 5 minutes, you don't have much of a sauce.  So stick to the 5 minutes.  It's a great chicken dish!

text:
Used fresh garlic (about 1 tbsp) instead of garlic powder, and added 1 tbsp tequilla and about 1/4 tsp dried hot pepper along with the lime juice. After adding these liquids and cooking for about 5 mins, added 1/2 cup chicken broth and cooked for another 5 mins. With the broth, there was sauce to put on the rice and meat.

Simple and easy to make; it's a good weeknight recipe.

text:
This chicken recipe has the potential to be quite flavorful but unfortunately, I found the salt and garlic powder to be way overpowering.  Overall, it was an alright recipe and likely something I will make again with a few adjustments.

(I actually just made it the second time without remembering that I had already rated and tried this recipe several years ago which alone speaks volume on the recipe's impact.  I gave it four stars initially but have changed it to three stars.  I've found way too many great concoctions in the last few years; this pales in comparison.)

text:
I tried this but then added my own twist to try to emulate Applebee's Fiesta Lime Chicken...I did the recipe almost exactly, added tequilla with the lime, but then at the end de-glazed the pan with broth. Then topped the chicken with salsa-ranch and Cheddar and placed on a bed of crumbled chips and broiled...sooooooooooo good! The flavor of the chicken is what really made it! Next time I'll just try the chicken shredded into tacos, or over nachos! MMMM! This is my new favorite chicken!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
They really need to have half star options. I debated.. Four.  Five.  Whatever - this is fabulous chicken.  Pound those breasts thin!  Double, if not TRIPLE, the spice mixture.  (I used Penzey's Pasta Sprinkle, in place of the thyme, and I never have Paprika on hand)  I did add 1/2 tbs of sugar, as my four year olds were supposed to eat this. Sauteed the chicken with red onion. Did add in some chicken broth into the oil/butter mix. And finally, added a tbs of Cuervo - which really came through and added a lot of depth. Husband ended up snaking the rest of my piece off my plate, while I went for another glass of wine. Will add this to the permanent recipe box!!

region:

country:
None
text:
This was pretty good.  I cut my chicken up into slices - I always wait to the last minute to thaw, so they cook faster when cut smaller.  The only other thing I changed was that I added fresh broccoli to the skillet at the lime/garlic powder point, and it steamed in minutes - and got a lot of garlic lime flavor.  I also removed the chicken and broccoli from the skillet and briefly reduced some white cooking wine and added some salt, pepper and a smidge of cornstarch for a slightly thicker sauce.  The flavor was very good.  We served it over jasmine rice.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677174.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Yummy! I was quite proud of myself with this one. The kids wanted their chicken fried, so I dusted the chicken breast w/flour, dipped in egg beaters, then dipped and coated with the seasoning mixture, and fried in the olive oil/butter. I mixed up flour, chicken broth, and Rose's lime juice (shook up in tupperware bowl to make sure there weren't any clumps), then added to the pan, stirring up all the brown bits and added more chicken broth till it was the consistency I wanted (squeezed more lime in too). I then cooked the other two chicken breasts in the sauce, for my husband and I. Served with white rice (with the sauce poured on top ... YUM!!)

I followed the recipe exactly, but halved the amount of cayenne pepper because we are whimps----just enough spice to have a kick but didn't make us cry! Even my 11-year-old loved it. This is going in my permanent rotation.
